container.heading: Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City 2024 Edition

annotation.text: This BFR Codes Article (2024 Edition) comprises the following standards and codes, as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore:

ul.li: International Residential Code, 1- and 2- Family Dwellings / 2021
International Swimming Pool and Spa Code / 2021

annotation.text: Ordinance 24-341 became effective May 22, 2024. Sections 2 and 3 of that Ordinance provide for its application to preexisting transactions as follows:

Section 3. And be it further ordained, That this Ordinance and the Building, Fire, and Related Codes adopted by it apply to all building operations for which a permit application is filed on or after the effective date of this Ordinance.

Section 4. And be it further ordained, That, except as expressly provided to the contrary in this Ordinance, any transaction, case, proceeding, investigation, or other matter validly begun before the effective date of this Ordinance and affected by or flowing from any law amended or repealed by this Ordinance, and any right, duty, or interest flowing from any ordinance amended or repealed by this Ordinance, remains valid after the effective date of this Ordinance and may be terminated, completed, enforced, or prosecuted as required or permitted by the prior law as though the amendment or repeal has not occurred. If any change in nomenclature involves a change in name or designation of any City agency or official, the successor agency or official has all the powers and obligations granted the predecessor agency or official.

container.heading: Maryland Building Performance Standards
container.section:
§s 1-101State action
(a)In general.The Maryland Building Performance Standards are adopted and, from time to time, amended by the Maryland Department of Labor under State Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 5.
(b)Contents.As amended effective May 29, 2023, these Standards consist of:
(1)the International Building Code (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and B};
(2)the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and C}; and
(3)the International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and D}.

section.heading: City adoption
section.text: The Maryland Building Performance Standards are adopted as part of the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City, subject to the following modifications:

para.text: in the International Building Code (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part II below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part II below;
in the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part X below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part X below; and
in the International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Parts IX-A and XI-B below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Parts IX-A and XI-B below.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The International Building Code (2021 Edition) is adopted as part of the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City, subject to the additions, deletions, amendments, and other modifications contained in this Part II.

para.heading: Codification.
para.text: Unless otherwise specified, chapter and section numbers in this Part II refer to the chapter and section numbers of the International Building Code.

section.heading: Maryland Building Performance Standards.
section.text: The Maryland Building Performance Standards contain certain State modifications to the International Building Code. The State modifications that Baltimore City has adopted are repeated in this Part II, for the user's convenience, in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision. These State modifications are labeled "MBPS Modification".

section.heading: City modifications.
section.text: The additions, deletions, amendments, and other modifications adopted by the City are as follows:

container.heading: Scope and Administration
container.text: {MBPS Modification ‒ Note to Chapter 1: Local jurisdictions are responsible for the implementation and enforcement of the Maryland Building Performance Standards. Refer to each local jurisdiction for local amendments to Chapter 1 of the IBC. Each local jurisdiction having authority shall establish ... implementation and enforcement procedures that include: (a) review and acceptance of appropriate plans; (b) issuance of building permits; (c) inspection of the work authorized by the building permits; and (d) issuance of use and occupancy certificates.}

para.heading: Title.
para.text: The regulations contained in this Code constitute and are known as the "Baltimore City Building Code". The Baltimore City Building Code, together with the standards and codes listed in § 101.4 {"Referenced codes"} of this Chapter, as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by these provisions, collectively constitute and are known as the "Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City".

para.heading: References to "this Code".
para.text: Throughout this Part II, all references to "this Code" refer to the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Exception 1: {Per MBPS Modification} Detached 1- and 2-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than 3 stories above grade plane in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures must comply with the International Residential Code.

Exception 2: {Per MBPS Modification} Existing buildings undergoing repair, alterations, or additions, and change of occupancy must comply with the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code, set forth in COMAR 09.12.58. {Note: The Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code comprises the 2021 International Existing Building Code, with State modifications.}
Exception 3: {Per MBPS Modification} Maintenance of residential structures and premises must comply with the Minimum Livability Code, as set forth in COMAR 09.12.54.

para.heading: Appendices.
para.text: The appendices to the International Building Code apply as follows:

para.heading: Appendices adopted.
para.text: The following appendices are adopted, with or without local modifications, as part of this Code:
Appendix C: "Group U – Agricultural Buildings".
Appendix D: "Downtown Fire District".
Appendix F: "Rodent Proofing".
Appendix H: "Signs".
Appendix I: "Patio Covers".
Appendix J: "Grading".

para.heading: Appendices not adopted.
para.text: The following appendices are not adopted as part of this Code:
Appendix A: "Employee Qualifications".
Appendix B: "Board of Appeals".
Appendix E: "Supplementary Accessibility Requirements".
Appendix G: "Flood Resistant Construction".
Appendix K: "Administrative Provisions".
Appendix L: "Earthquake Recording Instrumentation".
Appendix M: "Tsunami-Generated Flood Hazard".
Appendix N. "Replicable Buildings"

para.heading: Referenced codes.
para.text: The standards and codes listed in this § 101.4, as modified by these provisions and as referred to elsewhere in this Code, are part of the requirements of this Code to the extent prescribed by the reference.

para.heading: Electrical.
para.text: The National Electrical Code (2020 Edition), as modified in Part III of this Code, applies to the installation of electrical systems, including their alteration, repair, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances.

para.heading: Gas.
para.text: The International Fuel Gas Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part IV of this Code, applies to the installation of gas piping from the point of delivery, to gas appliances, and to related accessories as covered in this Code. These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances and the installation and operation of residential and commercial gas appliances, and related accessories.

para.heading: Mechanical.
para.text: The International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part V of this Code, applies to the installation, alterations, repairs, and replacement of mechanical systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances, including ventilating, heating, cooling, air-conditioning and refrigeration systems, incinerators, and other energy-related systems.

para.heading: Plumbing.
para.text: The International Plumbing Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VI of this Code, applies to the installation, alteration, repair, and replacement, use, or maintenance of or addition to plumbing systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances.

para.heading: Property maintenance.
para.text: The International Property Maintenance Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VII of this Code, applies to existing structures and premises; equipment and facilities; light, ventilation, space heating, sanitation, life, and fire safety hazards; responsibilities of owners, operators, and occupants; and occupancy of existing premises and structures.

para.heading: Fire prevention.
para.text: The International Fire Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VIII of this Code, applies to matters affecting or relating to prevention of structures, processes, and premises from the hazard of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials, or devices; from conditions hazardous to life, property, or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises; and from the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression, automatic sprinkler systems and alarm systems or fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation.

para.heading: Energy.
para.text: The International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Parts IX-A and IX-B of this Code, applies to all matters governing the design and construction of buildings for energy efficiency.

para.heading: Residential.
para.text: The International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition), as modified in Part X of this Code, applies to detached 1- and 2-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses), not more than 3 stories above grade plane in height, and their accessory structures.

para.heading: Green Construction.
para.text: The International Green Construction Code Construction (2021 Edition), as modified in Part XI of this Code, applies to construction requirements intended to reduce the negative impacts and increase the positive impacts of the built environment on the natural environment and building occupants.

para.heading: Swimming Pool and Spa.
para.text: The International Swimming Pool and Spa Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part XII of this Code, applies to the construction, alteration, movement, renovation, replacement, repair and maintenance of aquatic recreation facilities, pools and spas.

para.heading: References to former Codes.
para.text: All references in a violation, condemnation, or other notice, in a citation, or in the Baltimore City Code to any former version of the Building Code or to any provision of that Code are considered to refer to the comparable or otherwise applicable provisions of this Code.

para.heading: Existing conditions.
para.text: The legal occupancy of any structure existing on the date of adoption of this Code is permitted to continue without change, except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, the International Property Maintenance Code, or the International Fire Code.

para.heading: Structures owned by City.
para.text: This Code does not apply to any structure (other than a building) that is owned by the City, to the extent that the structure:
is located on, over, or under a street, alley, or other public way or land, and

is designed, constructed, controlled, and maintained by and under the authority and supervision of the Director of Public Works, the Director of General Services, or the Director of Transportation, whichever has jurisdiction, or an authorized representative of the applicable Director.

para.heading: Public service structures on streets.
para.text: This Code does not apply to any pole, conduit, tunnel, pipe line, manhole, or other similar surface or subsurface structure, including its equipment, that is owned and controlled by a public service corporation, to the extent that:
the structure is located on, over, or under a street, alley, or other public way or land,
its construction is authorized by the City, and

its installation is regulated and supervised by the Director of Public Works, the Director of General Services, or the Director of Transportation, whichever has jurisdiction, or an authorized representative of the applicable Director.

para.heading: Property owned or leased by United States or Maryland.
para.text: Except as specified in § 102.9.1, land owned by the United States or by the State of Maryland, including any structure owned by either and located on the land, is exempt from this Code.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: The following are not exempt from this Code:
land or structures leased by the United States or the State of Maryland from a private owner,
land or structures leased by a private owner from the United States or the State of Maryland, and
land or structures held by the United States or the State of Maryland pursuant to the foreclosure of a residential mortgage.

para.heading: Waterways.
para.text: Other than work done by the United States or the State of Maryland, all construction done along the shoreline and waterways within the City must:
comply with this Code, and
be approved by:
the Department of Public Works,
the Department of General Services,
the Department of Transportation,
the Department of Planning,
the Fire Department,
the Maryland Department of the Environment, and
the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.

para.heading: Railroad facilities.
para.text: Railroad facilities within a railroad right-of-way are exempt from the provisions of this Code, except for those provisions that relate to sanitary maintenance. However, privately owned structures within a right-of-way are not exempt unless they are ancillary to the railroad.

para.heading: Moved structures.
para.text: Structures that are moved into or within Baltimore City:
must comply with the provisions of this Code for new structures, and
may not be used or occupied, in whole or in part, until the Building Official approves an occupancy permit for the structure.

para.heading: Compliance with Code required.
para.text: No structure, premises, land, or equipment may be constructed, altered, added to, repaired, rehabilitated, demolished, moved, located, used, occupied, or maintained in violation of this Code.

para.heading: Construction of structure.
para.text: When constructed, every structure must be located so that it does not create a violation of this Code.

para.heading: Relocation, etc., of lot lines, etc.
para.text: No lot or property line may be moved or relocated and no lot or parcel of land may be subdivided in any way that creates a violation of this Code for any structure.

para.heading: Compliance with other laws.
para.text: To the extent applicable, all work must also comply with:
the Critical Area Management Program of Baltimore City,
the Baltimore City Forest and Tree Conservation Program,
the Baltimore City Sustainability Plan,
the Zoning Code of Baltimore City,
City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"},
any applicable Urban Renewal Plan,
the Department of Public Works' rules and regulations governing:
stormwater management,
soil erosion and sediment control, and
discharges to the storm drain system,
the Department of Transportation's rules and regulations governing:
encroachments into the public right-of-way,
developer's agreements, and
blasting,
the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act,
the Maryland Accessibility Code,
the Floodplain Management Code, and
all other applicable laws, rules, and regulations of the United States, the State of Maryland, and the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Enforcement agency.
para.text: This Code is administered and enforced by the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development and its Commissioner. Accordingly, in this Code:
"Department of Building Safety" or "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development, and
"Building Official", means the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or an authorized representative of the Commissioner.

para.heading: Employee restrictions.
para.text: An officer or employee of the Department may not:

engage in or directly or indirectly be connected with the furnishing of labor, materials, or appliances or the preparation of plans or specifications for the construction, alteration, addition, repair, rehabilitation, demolition, moving, or maintenance of a structure, unless the officer or employee is the owner of the structure, or
engage in any work that conflicts with his or her official duties or with the interests of the Department.

section.heading: Duties and Powers of Building Official

para.heading: General.
para.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, the Building Official:
administers and enforces all provisions of this Code and the provisions of all other ordinances, laws, {rules,} or regulations relating to the matters provided for in this Code, and

may act on any question relative to the manner of and the materials to be used in the construction, alteration, addition, repair, rehabilitation, demolition, moving, location, use, occupancy, and maintenance of all structures and in the installation of equipment.

para.heading: Interpretations, rules, and regulations.
para.text: The Building Official may:
render interpretations of this Code, and
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this Code.

para.heading: Determination of substantially improved or substantially damaged existing structures in flood hazard areas.
para.text: For applications for reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of an existing structure in a flood hazard area, the Building Official must examine the construction documents and prepare findings with regard to whether the structure has sustained "substantial damage" and whether the proposed improvement is a "substantial improvement", as these terms are defined in and calculated under the Floodplain Management Code. The Building Official must submit these findings to the Floodplain Manager for a determination of "substantial improvement". Applications determined by the Floodplain Manager to constitute a "substantial improvement" require full compliance with the requirements of the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: Right of entry.
para.text: In the performance of his or her duties, the Building Official may enter any land, structure, or premises in the City to enforce this Code, at any reasonable time or, in an emergency that might endanger public health or safety, at any time.

para.heading: Entry without notice or warrant.
para.text: Neither a search warrant nor prior notice is needed in any of the following circumstances:
if entry is by permission or at the request of an occupant of the land, structure, or premises or a person with apparent right of possession,
if the land, structure, or premises is open and accessible to members of the general public,
if the Building Official reasonably believes that an imminent danger to health or safety exists or might exist, or
immediately after an accident or disaster that causes the Building Official to believe that immediate entry is necessary for investigative purposes or to protect property or public health or safety.

para.heading: Authority to seek warrant.
para.text: Where appropriate, the Building Official may seek a search warrant to enter any land, structure, or premises in the City to make an inspection or to take any other authorized action to administer and enforce:
this Code (including the standards and codes incorporated in it), or
any of the following (collectively "related laws"):
the Health Code of Baltimore City,
the Zoning Code of Baltimore City,
an Urban Renewal Plan,
City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, or
any other related statute, ordinance, rule, or regulation for the protection of the health and safety of the residents of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Warrant after prior notice.
para.text: Before the Building Official may apply for a warrant to make a routine inspection or spot check to determine if a violation exists, the Building Official must give prior notice of his or her intent to the occupant or other person with apparent right of possession or, in the case of an unoccupied structure or premises, to the owner, the owner's agent, or other person in apparent control of the structure or premises.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The notice must:
state the date and time at which the Building Official will be present to make the inspection or spot check, and
inform the person notified that he or she may reschedule the inspection or spot check to a reasonable date and time by contacting the Building Official before the stated date.

para.heading: Service of notice – Occupied property.
para.text: If the structure or premises is occupied, the notice must be either:
mailed or delivered to the occupant or person with apparent right of possession, or
posted conspicuously at or near the entrance to the structure or premises.

para.heading: Service of notice – Unoccupied property.
para.text: If the structure or premises is unoccupied, the notice must be mailed or delivered to the last-known address of the owner, agent, or other person in apparent control.

para.heading: Obtaining warrant.
para.text: After notice has been given, if the person notified fails to arrange for, denies, or unduly delays the entry, the Building Official may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for a search warrant to authorize entry for the inspection or spot check.

para.heading: Probable cause.
para.text: Probable cause for a search warrant under this § 104.6.3 exists if:
the notice required by this § 104.6.3 has been given, and
the inspection is:
a spot check made at random or restricted to a few sample structures or premises in a designated area to determine if a building-by-building survey is necessary,
a routine inspection based on a general administrative plan for the enforcement of this Code or any related law, or
a routine inspection to determine compliance with a notice or order issued under § 123 {"Notices"} of this Code.

para.heading: Warrant without prior notice.
para.text: The Building Official may apply for a search warrant to enter a structure or premises without giving the prior notice otherwise required by § 104.6.3, if there is probable cause to believe that a violation of this Code or a related law exists in the structure or on the premises.

para.heading: Probable cause.
para.text: Probable cause for a search warrant under this § 104.6.4 includes, among other appropriate circumstances, the following:

the inspection is to identify lead-based hazards in a dwelling unit that is the last-reported address of a child who, by notice from a health care provider or the State Department of the Environment to the Building Official or the Health Commissioner, is reported to have been diagnosed with a venous blood-lead level of 5 micrograms per deciliter or more, or

untreated lead-based paint hazards have been found in a unit of a multiple-family dwelling in which a child who has been diagnosed with a venous blood-lead level of 5 micrograms per deciliter or more resides and entry is needed to other units of the dwelling to determine compliance with law.

para.heading: Application for warrant.
para.text: The application for a search warrant must be:
signed and sworn to by the Building Official, and
accompanied by an affidavit containing facts within the personal knowledge of the affiant:
that probable cause for issuance of a search warrant exists, and
in cases where prior notice is required, that notice has been given and entry has not been arranged for or has been denied or unduly delayed by the person notified.

para.heading: Contents of warrant.
para.text: The search warrant must name or describe, with reasonable particularity:
the place to be inspected,
the reason for the inspection, and
the name of the applicant on whose written application the warrant was issued.

para.heading: Execution of warrant.
para.text: An inspection under the search warrant must be made within 15 days of the date the warrant was issued. At the end of that 15-day period, the warrant is void.

para.heading: Dwelling units.
para.text: Except as provided in § 104.6.8.1, no inspector who gains entrance to a dwelling for the purpose of enforcing this Code or any related law may obtain or furnish evidence of, or testify to, any offense other than violations of this Code or of any related law.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: The limitations of § 104.6.8 do not apply to:
a felony, or
a misdemeanor involving an act of violence and committed in the inspector's presence.

para.heading: Liability.
para.reason: Not Adopted. See State Courts Article § 5-302.

para.heading: Flood hazard areas.
para.text: {Note: For the establishment of Regulated Flood Hazard Areas and the special regulations and limitations governing development within those areas, see the Floodplain Management Code, City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, Division I {"Floodplain Management"}.}

para.heading: Alternative materials and methods.
para.text: The provisions of this Code are not intended to prevent the installation of any material or to prohibit any method of construction not specifically prescribed by this Code, as long as that alternative has been approved. An alternative material or method of construction may be approved if the Building Official finds in writing that, for the purpose intended:
the proposed alternative is satisfactory and complies with the intent of this Code, and
the material, method, or work offered is at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this Code in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire resistance, durability, and safety.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed item 2 of 104.1 of this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: A permit issued by the Building Official is required before any person may do any of the following work:
construct, alter, add to, repair, rehabilitate, demolish, or move any structure,
change the use of any structure or land,
install or alter any equipment subject to this Code,
move a lot line that affects any structure,
perform any grading or excavating,
undertake, cause, or allow any addition, alteration or other action described in either of the following provisions of City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}:
§ 8-2(a) {"Building permit required: Exterior structures"}, describing actions for or with respect to any structure:
within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District,
on the Landmark List: Exteriors, or
on the potential-Landmark List: Exteriors, or
§ 8-2(b) {"Building permit required: Public interiors"}, describing actions for or with respect to any structure:
on the Landmark List: Public Interiors, or
on the potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors, or
on transfer of ownership or operation of property, continue any of the following uses:
banquet hall (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(c) {"Banquet hall."}),
body art establishment (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(j) {"Body art establishment."}),
carry-out food shop (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(t) {"Carry-out food shop."}),
congregate living facilities (as defined in § 202.1 of the Baltimore City Building Code),
day-care center: adult or child (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code §§ 1-304(y) and (z) {"Day-care center: Adult"} and {"Day-care center: Child"}, respectively),
drive-through facility (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-305(h) {"Drive-through facility."}),
entertainment: indoor or live (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code §§ 1-306(b) and 1-306(c) {"Entertainment: Indoor"} and {"Entertainment: Live"}, respectively),
fuel station (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(t) {"Fuel station."}),
health-care clinic (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-307(f) {"Health-care clinic."}),
lodge or social club (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-308(q) {"Lodge or social club."}),
lounge (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-309(h-1) {"Lounge."}),
pawn shop (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-311(l) {"Pawn shop."}),
personal services establishment (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-311(o) {"Personal services establishment."}),
residential care facility (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(p) {"Residential care facility"}),
restaurant (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(s) {"Restaurant."}),
retail: big box establishment (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(t) {“Retail: Big box Establishment”}),
retail goods establishment – with or without alcoholic beverage sales (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(u) {"Retail goods establishment."}),
rooming house (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-313(b) {"Rooming house."}),
supportive housing facility (as defined in § 202.2.56 of this Code), or
tavern (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-314(a) {"Tavern."}).

para.heading: By whom application to be made.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in Chapter 27 {"Electrical"}, Chapter 28 {"Mechanical Systems"}, and Chapter 29 {"Plumbing Systems"}, the application for a permit must be made as follows:
for a demolition or moving permit, by the owner of the property to be demolished or moved,
for a permit to remove formstone, paint, or other material from exterior surfaces, by the licensed contractor employed to do the proposed work,
for a permit to do work involving underpinning or a retaining foundation wall, by the licensed contractor employed to do the proposed work, and
for all other permits, by:
the owner or lessee of the structure,
the agent of the owner or lessee, or
the licensed engineer or architect employed in connection with the proposed work.

para.heading: Work done without permit.
para.text: A person who does any work without a permit, or outside or beyond the scope of a permit, or in a manner inconsistent with plans or drawings approved as part of a permit application, or after a permit is revoked for any reason, must obtain a permit for that work, even if already completed, and pay the appropriate permit fee and penalty surcharge.

para.heading: Special professional services.
para.text: In addition to and without limiting any other requirements of or authority granted by this Code, the Building Official may require, as a term or condition of a permit, that a registered design professional or other licensed specialist or expert perform specific work or sign and seal specific plans, computations, specifications, or statements.

para.heading: Work exempt from permit.
para.text: An exemption from the permit requirements of this Code does not authorize any work to be done in a manner that violates a provision of this Code or of any other law. Permits are not required for the following:

para.reason: As in IBC and subject to all local, state, and federal laws

para.text: Interior painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops, and similar interior finish work.

Shade cloth or plastic film structures, commonly known as "hoophouses", constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes. not including service systems. The covering of the structure must be a material that conforms to NFPA 701 standards.
Removal of debris, except in cases of interior or exterior demolition.
Boarding exterior openings with plywood.
Minor repair or patching of drywall or plaster.
Replacing roof shingles.
Replacing roof tarring.
Installing a temporary door on a structure subject to a vacant building notice.

para.heading: Application for permit.
para.text: To obtain a permit, the applicant must first file an application on the form provided by the Building Official for that purpose. The application must:
identify and describe the work to be covered under the permit,
describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by legal description, street address, or similar description that will readily identify and definitely locate the proposed building or work,
indicate the use and occupancy for which the proposed work is intended,
specify the gross floor area, as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(j) {"Floor Area: Gross (GFA)"}, involved in the proposed work,
specify the number of dwelling units, if any, involved in the proposed work,
be accompanied by the construction documents and other information required by § 107 {"Construction Documents"} of this Code, and

if the property is located within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District or included on the City's Landmark List or Potential-Landmark List, be forwarded to the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation, for review and action under City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc., to or Affecting Properties"},
state the valuation of the proposed work,
if the proposed work will replace any existing structure, be accompanied by photographs that depict the existing conditions and existing structures on the site,
include a detailed disposal plan on the form provided by the Building Official for that purpose, if:
the proposed work includes interior or exterior demolition, and
the Building Official requires the applicant to provide a detailed disposal plan,
identify the parties by providing:
the full names, phone numbers, addresses, and (if available) email addresses of the owner, lessee, and applicant,
the full name, phone number, address, and (if available) email address of a person who can be contacted at all times in case of an emergency, and

if the owner, lessee, or applicant is a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or other entity, full names, phone numbers, addresses, and (if available) email addresses of its officers, partners, or members, as the case may be,
provide any other data and information that the Building Official requires,
be signed by the applicant, or the applicant's authorized agent,
if signed by an agent, be accompanied by:
proof of agency, and
proof of the agent's identity, by copy or presentation of a valid Maryland driver's license or other Maryland identification, and
if the application is for a permit for public assemblies – annual or a permit for public assemblies – short term, as described in section 109.6.5 of this Code, the application shall be:
filed at least 45 days before the event date, and
signed by the applicant or the applicant’s agent.

para.heading: General.
para.text: The Building Official must examine all applications for permits within a reasonable time after filing. If the application or the proposed work does not conform to the requirements of this Code or any other applicable law, the Building Official must reject the application in writing, stating the reasons for the rejection. If the Building Official is satisfied that the application and the proposed work conform to the requirements of this Code and all other applicable laws, the Building Official must issue the permit as soon as practicable.

para.heading: Referral to assess need for traffic mitigation.
para.text: Within 15 business days of receiving a completed application, the Building Official must refer the application and all accompanying documents to the Director of Transportation, for review and action under Chapter 38 {"Traffic Impact and Mitigation"} of this Code, if:
traffic mitigation requirements for the proposed work have not already been complied with in accordance with this Code or the Baltimore City Zoning Code; and
the proposed work:
is in a Traffic-Mitigation Zone designated under Chapter 38 {"Traffic Impact and Mitigation"} of this Code and involves 10 or more dwelling units,
involves 15,000 sq. ft. or more of gross floor area (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(j)), or
involves 50 or more dwelling units.

para.heading: Bond for exterior removal of formstone, paint, etc.
para.text: An application for a permit to remove formstone, paint, or other material from exterior surfaces must be accompanied by evidence satisfactory to the Building Official that the applicant has obtained a bond to cover the City's expense in the event of a spill or failure to properly dispose of hazardous waste. The bond must be in an amount of at least $10,000.

para.heading: Expiration; extension; reinstatement for final inspection.
para.text: Unless an extension is granted, every permit expires and becomes invalid on the expiration date specified on the permit or, if earlier, as provided in this § 105.5.

para.heading: Expiration – General.
para.text: Except as specified in § 105.5.2, a permit expires if:
the work authorized by the permit is not begun on the site within 180 days after the permit is issued, or
the work authorized by the permit is abandoned or suspended on the site for 180 days or more.

para.heading: Expiration – Condemnation, demolition.
para.text: A permit issued to comply with a condemnation notice served under § 123 {"Notices"} of this Code or to comply with a demolition order issued under § 116 {"Unsafe Structures"} of this Code expires if:
the work authorized by the permit is not begun on the site within 30 days after the permit is issued, or
the work authorized by the permit is not completed within 90 days after the permit is issued.

para.heading: Extensions – General.
para.text: On a timely written application and for justifiable cause demonstrated, the Building Official may grant 1 or more extensions. Except as specified in § 105.5.5:
the application for an extension must be made within 90 days after the permit expires, and
each extension is limited to a period of not more than 180 days, unless otherwise authorized by the Building Official.

para.heading: Extensions – Condemnation, demolition.
para.text: For a permit issued to comply with a condemnation notice or a demolition order:
the application for an extension must be made within 90 days after the date that the permit expired and
each extension must be limited to a period of not more than 90 days.

para.heading: Reinstatement for final inspection.
para.text: An expired permit may be reinstated by the Building Official for a final inspection if:
the application for reinstatement is made within 3 years of the permit's expiration;
all rough-in inspections were completed and approved by the Building Official; and
all of the work is complete.

para.heading: Single reinstatement allowed.
para.text: An expired permit may be reinstated by the Building Official for a final inspection only once.

para.heading: Compliance with violation notice or order.
para.text: The expiration date of a permit does not in any way extend the time required to comply with a violation notice or order.

para.heading: Suspension or revocation.
para.text: The Building Official may suspend or revoke a permit issued under this Code if:
the work is being done in violation of the permit, of this Code, or of any other applicable law{, rule,} or regulation,
the permit was issued:
in error or on the basis of incorrect, inaccurate, or incomplete information, or
in violation of this Code or of any other law{, rule,} or regulation, or

any Federal, State, or City agency suspends or revokes any license or takes any other action that diminishes the ability to use any portion of the property in any way for which the permit was granted under this Code.

para.heading: Separate structures.
para.text: Whenever work is being done on two or more independent structures on the same property, a separate permit is required for each independent structure.

para.heading: Special requirements for demolition or moving.
Pre-permit requirements.
para.text: A permit may not be granted for demolishing or moving a structure unless the applicant complies with the following.

para.heading: Inspector consultation.
para.text: The applicant must have attended an on-site, pre-demolition or pre-moving inspector consultation to discuss and confirm:
appropriate hosing/wetting requirements and procedures,
notification requirements, and
any other matters the Building Official requires.

para.heading: Written notice to adjoining owners, etc.
para.text: The applicant must have given written notice to:
the owners of all properties that are physically attached to the structure subject to demolition or moving, and
the owners of any wired or other facilities that might have to be temporarily removed because of the proposed work.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The written notice must:
indicate the intent to demolish or move the structure,
specify when the work is expected to begin,
identify the contractor scheduled to perform the demolition or moving, and
provide the full name, phone number, address, and (if available) email address of an agent of the contractor who can be reached at all times in case of an emergency.

para.heading: Pre-demolition, moving requirements.
para.text: Before beginning any demolition or moving operations, the permit holder must comply with the following.

para.heading: Posted notice.
para.text: Public notice of the demolition or moving must be posted on the premises at least 5 days before the scheduled action, but not more than 10 days before the scheduled action.

para.heading: Sign requisites – General.
para.text: The sign must be:
at least 4 feet wide and 3 feet high,
written in black lettering, at least 2 inches high, on a yellow background,
conspicuously posted, clearly visible and legible to the public, and with the bottom of the sign not less than 5 feet nor more than 10 feet above ground level, and
maintained in good condition until the time of the demolition or moving.

para.heading: Sign requisites – Multiple structures.
para.text: If the demolition or moving involves 2 or more structures on the same or adjoining properties:

1 sign meeting the specifications of § 105.9.2.1.1 must be conspicuously posted, clearly visible and legible to the public, and with the bottom of the sign not less than 5 feet nor more than 10 feet above ground level, and
each individual structure must be posted with a sign that is:
at least 17 inches wide and 11 inches high,
written in black lettering on a yellow background,
conspicuously posted, clearly visible and legible to the public, and with the bottom of the sign not less than 5 feet nor more than 10 feet above ground level, and
maintained in good condition until the time of the demolition or moving.

para.heading: Proof of posting.
para.text: The permit holder must submit to the Building Official photographic evidence of the posting required by this section.

para.heading: Inspector presence.
para.text: At least 24 hours before beginning the demolition or moving operation, the contractor must contact the Building Official to schedule the presence of an inspector at the beginning of the demolition or moving operation.

para.heading: Failure to comply.
para.text: Failure to comply with the requirements of this § 105.9 may result in revocation of the permit.

para.heading: Required corrections.
para.text: The issuance of a permit does not prevent the Building Official from later requiring the correction of errors in any plans, drawings, work, or operations.

para.heading: Post -work proof of disposal.
para.text: If a permit holder was required to submit a detailed disposal plan as described in § 105.3.10 of this chapter, and the permit holder fails to submit proof of waste and refuse disposal to the Building Official upon completion of the work for which the permit was granted:
the Building Official may not finalize the permit,
the Building Official may not issue an Occupancy Permit for the structure on which the work was performed, and
the permit holder is subject to a penalty established under City Code Article 1, § 40-14(e)(5c) {"Violations to which subtitle applies"}.

para.heading: Inspection registration permits.
para.text: An inspection registration permit issued by the Building Official is required before any person may use any land or structure for:

a place of public assembly, including any assembly hall, auditorium, bowling lane, dance hall, exhibition hall, motion picture theater, musical hall, opera house, pool parlor, skating rink, sports arena, stadium, or theater, or
any roof tank or roof sign.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Exception 2: Construction documents may be submitted electronically through the City's permit system if the submission complies with the guidelines established in the Permit Applicant User Guide.

para.heading: Site plan.
para.text: The construction documents submitted with the application for permit must be accompanied by a site plan.

para.heading: General requirements.
para.text: The site plan must:
show to scale the size and location of new construction and existing structures on the site, distances from lot lines, the established street grades, and the proposed finished grades,
show, as applicable, Regulated Flood Hazard Areas, Floodways, and flood-protection elevations,
be drawn in accordance with an accurate boundary line survey, and
comport with all other requirements of this section.

para.heading: Demolition.
para.text: In the case of demolition, the site plan must show construction to be demolished and the location and size of existing structures and construction that are to remain on the site.

para.heading: Specifications, photographs, additional information.
para.text: The site plan must:
be drawn in accordance with the specifications required by rules or regulations adopted by the Building Official in consultation with the Director ofTransportation, and
contain any additional information required by those rules or regulations.

para.heading: Exterior balconies and elevated walking surfaces.
Waiver or modification.
para.text: The Building Official may waive or modify the requirement for a site plan if the application is for alteration or repair or if otherwise warranted.

para.heading: Temporary power.
para.text: The Building Official may give permission to temporarily supply power to a structure that is not yet complete, as long as all work complies with the requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Permit fees.
para.text: A permit for construction, alteration, demolition, moving, or other building operation is not valid unless the fees prescribed in this Code have been paid, nor is any amendment or extension to a permit valid unless the prescribed additional fee has been paid. Payment must be made before issuance of the permit, amendment, or extension.

para.heading: Other fees.
para.text: The payment of the fee for all work done concurrently or in connection with the work contemplated by a permit does not relieve the applicant or permit holder from the payment of other fees prescribed by law for water taps, sewer connections, electrical permits, signs and display structures, marquees, or other appurtenant structures, or fees for inspections, occupancy permits, or other privileges or requirements, whether within or without the jurisdiction of the Department.

para.heading: Minimum fees and service charges.
para.text: Fees or service charges for the various permits, certificates, inspections, tests, or other services provided under this Code are as specified in this § 109. Unless otherwise specified, the minimum fee or service charge is $25. All fees are to be rounded to the nearest dollar.

para.heading: General.
para.text: No fee or other service charge paid for any application, permit, certificate, inspection, test, or other service may be refunded, in whole or in part, except as provided in this § 109.4.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: Except as provided in § 109.4.3:
if no work has been done nor any privilege enjoyed under a permit, certificate, inspection, test, or other service, a refund may be granted of not more than 50% of the fee or service charge paid; and
in no event may any refund be granted on any fee or charge of less than $1,000.

para.heading: Administrative error.
para.text: If the Building Official revokes a permit because of an administrative error that, through no fault of the applicant, was made in issuing the permit, the applicant is entitled to:
apply for and receive a full refund of the fee paid for the revoked permit, or
request that the fee paid for the revoked permit be applied and credited to the fee due for a new permit to replace the one revoked.

para.heading: Duplicate or additional documents.
para.text: The charges for copies or duplicates of permits, certificates, and other documents are:
for photocopies of documents other than approved plans, $1 for the 1st page and 50¢ for each additional page,
for duplicates of permits other than approved plans, $10 for each duplicate issued, and
for copies or duplicates of approved plans, $10 per sheet plus any charge involved in reproducing them.
Exception: The fee for photocopies of violation notices, condemnation notices, and records related to either, will be waived if the notices are:
for a residential property, and
the copies and the fee waiver are requested by:
the current owner of the property, as evidenced by a recorded deed, or
a current occupant of the property, as evidenced by an executed lease or other record satisfactory to the Building Official.

para.heading: Deposit for copies.
para.text: The Building Official may require a deposit in the amount of $100 for any copy or duplicate request that:
is for photocopies of documents, other than approved plans or permits, estimated to be in excess of 200 pages; or
is for photocopies or duplicates of more than 10 approved plans or permits.

para.heading: Partial permits.
para.text: For a partial permit issued under this Code:
the charge is at the rate of:
$10 for each $1,000 worth of work up to $1,000,000 worth of work, plus
$5 for each $1,000 worth of work in excess of $1,000,000, and
the minimum charge is:
$100 for 1- and 2-family dwellings, and
$250 for all other structures.

para.heading: Permit extensions.
para.text: For a permit extension issued under this Code, the charge is as follows:
If the application for extension is made within 90 days after the permit expires, the fee for the extension is $25.

If the application for extension is made between 31-90 days after the permit expires, the fee for the extension is 50% of the original permit fee. Alternatively, the applicant may apply for a new permit for the work remaining to be completed, with the fee for that permit to be based on the scope of that remaining work.

para.heading: Permit amendments.
para.text: For an amendment to a permit, the charge is as follows:
For each amendment that involves a work area not originally applied for, the charge is the appropriate fee for the work contemplated, with a minimum fee as follows:
For each amendment within the work area originally applied for, the charge is the appropriate fee for the work contemplated, with a minimum fee as follows:

para.text: To add or change a contractor, the charge is $25 per application.

para.heading: Preliminary Project Review.
para.text: For a "Preliminary Review" of a proposed project, the charge is $50 for each half hour.

para.heading: Revised drawings.
para.text: For revised drawings, the charge is $10 for each sheet submitted, with a minimum charge of $25.

para.heading: Application fee.
para.text: Before an application for any permit or certificate is processed, the applicant must pay a nonrefundable application fee as follows:
For applications that do not require the submission of construction documents for plan review:
For applications that require the submission of construction documents for plan review:

para.heading: Overtime fee.
para.text: For each inspection or reinspection that, at the request of the owner or owner's agent, is made outside normal working hours, a charge is imposed at the rate of $50 an hour for each inspector, with a minimum charge, payable in advance, of $200 for each inspector.

para.heading: Reinspection fee.
para.text: If the owner or owner's agent schedules an inspection and, for any reason, a reinspection of the same work is required, the charge, payable in advance, is as follows:
$50 for a 1st reinspection,
$100 for a 2nd reinspection, and
$125 for a 3rd and every subsequent reinspection.

para.heading: Penalty surcharge.
para.text: A surcharge is imposed on any permit that is issued for work begun or completed:
without a permit,
beyond the scope of a permit or in a manner inconsistent with plans or drawings approved as part of a permit application, or
during the suspension or after the revocation of a permit for that work.

para.heading: Amount – In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this § 109.5.9, the amount of the surcharge is the greater of $1,000 or 50% of the permit fee.

para.heading: Amount – Demolition work.
para.text: For demolition work done without the proper permit or in violation of the terms of a permit, the surcharge is 50¢ for each cubic foot of the structure before the demolition.

para.heading: Reductions.
para.text: The Building Official may reduce the amount of a surcharge imposed by this § 109.5.9:
on written application and justifiable cause demonstrated, and
in accordance with applicable standards and criteria contained in the rules and regulations adopted under this Code.

para.heading: Surcharge in addition to other fines, etc.
para.text: A surcharge imposed by this § 109.5.9 is in addition to any other fine or penalty imposed under this Code or any other law or regulation.

para.heading: Unpaid surcharge.
para.text: An unpaid surcharge shall be collected and a lien placed in the manner set forth in § 118 of this Code.

para.heading: Violation reports.
para.text: The charge for a violation report, whether obtained from the Department or from the Bureau of Liens, is $30, in addition to the charge for a lien certificate.

para.heading: Uncollected payments.
para.text: The charge for each unsuccessful attempt to collect a payment is $50.

para.text: For erecting, placing, hanging, or reconstructing any consolidated area of signage, as described in Baltimore City Zoning Code Title 17, Subtitle 3 {"Sign Dimension and Quantity Measurement Methodology"}, the fee is $1 a square foot, with a minimum of $13 for each consolidated area of signage.

The rates in items j and k are based on the gross square feet area of the sign face or faces. No fee is charged for signs less than 100 square feet (9.29 sq. m.) and used exclusively for advertising the sale or lease of the property on which they are posted.
For repairing, painting, and rehanging any sign in the same place, the fee is $25 for each sign.

para.text: For each temporary structure, the fee is $20 a year for each 500 square feet or fraction of 500 square feet of gross floor area.

para.text: Sediment and erosion control permit and review fees will be assessed by the Department of Public Works in accordance with the fee schedule established from time to time by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: DPW and DoT review charges.
para.text: A fee of $100 will be charged for each review of a permit application by the Department of Public Works or by the Department of Transportation. Additional fees for consultation meetings with the applicant will be charged at the rate of $50 for each half hour.

para.text: For inspection registration permits, the fees are as follows:

para.heading: Public assemblies – Annual.
para.text: For public assemblies, the annual fee is:

If the net proceeds from any of these assemblies are to be used continuously and exclusively for the benefit of a nonprofit, tax-exempt charitable or religious organization, then, on the organization's submission with the permit application of evidence documenting its qualifications, the permit fee is waived.

para.heading: Public assemblies – Short term.
para.text: For public assemblies for which an annual permit has not been obtained, fees are charged as follows for each 10,000 square feet (929.03 sq. m.) or fraction of 10,000 square feet (929.03 sq. m.):

If the net proceeds from any of these activities, other than amusement devices, are to be used exclusively for the benefit of a nonprofit, tax-exempt charitable or religious organization, then, on the organization's submission with the permit application of evidence documenting its qualifications, the permit fee is waived.

para.text: For roof tanks and roof signs, the annual fee is:

para.heading: Fees for miscellaneous work.
para.text: Permit fees for miscellaneous work, operations, and other purposes, not elsewhere provided for in this Code, are charged at the rate of $10 for each $1,000 or fraction of $1,000 of estimated cost.

para.heading: Building Code Permit Tax.
para.text: A tax is levied and imposed on every issuance of a permit under this Code. The amount of the tax is 5% of the final cost of that permit rounded up to the nearest whole dollar. The funds so collected are to be deposited to the General Fund and accounted for in a revenue account entitled "Homeless Relief Assistance", with the legislative intent that an equivalent amount be appropriated in the future for the relief of the homeless.

para.heading: Lowest floor elevation.
para.text: In a flood hazard area, on placement of the lowest floor and before undertaking any further vertical construction, the elevation certificate required by the Floodplain Management Code must be submitted to the Building Official.

para.heading: Final inspection.
para.text: The final inspection must be made after all work required by the building permit is completed.

para.heading: Flood hazard documentation.
para.text: For structures in a flood hazard area, documentation of the elevation of the lowest floor, as required by the Floodplain Management Code, must be submitted to the Building Official before the final inspection.

para.name: 111.1to111.4
para.reason: As in IBC. But Note: The "certificate of occupancy" to which the IBC refers is known in Baltimore City as an "occupancy permit".

para.heading: Certificate of completion.
para.text: Within 10 days of written application, the Building Official will issue a certificate of completion if all work authorized by a building permit has been satisfactorily completed in compliance with this Code. The certificate certifies the satisfactory completion of the work and the purpose for which the structure may be used in its several parts.

para.heading: Unlawful acts.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to:
construct, alter, add to, repair, rehabilitate, demolish, move, locate, use, occupy, or maintain any structure, premises, land, or equipment contrary to or in conflict with or in violation of:
any provision of this Code,
any provision of City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, or

any provision of any rule, regulation, decision, permit, notice. or order issued under this Code or under City Code Article 6 by the Building Official, by the Commission for Architectural and Historical Preservation, or by any other person, board, department, bureau, commission, or agency with jurisdiction,
otherwise fail to comply with any provision of this Code, of City Code Article 6, or of any rule, regulation, decision, permit, notice, or order issued under this Code or City Code Article 6, or
cause any of these acts or omissions to be done.

para.heading: Violation notice or order.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this Code, the Building Official may serve a violation notice or order on any person legally responsible for the construction, alteration, addition, repair, rehabilitation, demolition, moving, location, use, occupancy, or maintenance of any structure, premises, land, or equipment in violation of any provision of:
this Code, or
a plan approved under this Code, or
a permit or certificate issued under this Code.

para.heading: Tenor of notice or order.
para.text: The notice or order may direct:
the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition, and
the abatement of the violation, which may include restoration to the prior condition.

para.heading: Enforcement generally.
para.text: If a violation is not discontinued or abated within 14 days of the issuance of a violation notice, or if the violation notice or order is not complied with within 14 days of the issuance of a violation notice, the Building Official may institute or cause to be instituted any appropriate legal proceedings. Provided however, for an emergent issue, as determined by the Building Official, the 14 day period to abate or comply with the notice or order may be waived by the Building Official and the Building Official may institute or cause to be instituted any appropriate legal proceedings.

para.heading: Types of proceedings.
para.text: Enforcement proceedings may include:
injunctive or other equity proceedings, including:
an action initiated by a code-enforcement-injunction citation under City Code Article 19, § 71-3 {"Code enforcement injunction"}, or
an action for appointment of a receiver under § 121 {"Vacant Building Receiver"} of this Code,
criminal prosecution, including a prosecution initiated by a prepayable criminal citation under City Code Article 19, § 71-2 {"Prepayable criminal citations"}, and
administrative proceedings, including one initiated by an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, § 40-14 {"Violations to which subtitle applies"}.

para.heading: Remedies not exclusive.
para.text: In pursuing a violation, the Building Official may use any 1 or more available remedies or enforcement actions. The initiation of any 1 remedy or enforcement action does not preclude pursuing any other remedy or enforcement action authorized by law. Neither damages, irreparable injury, nor the lack of an adequate remedy at law is a prerequisite to enforcement in equity.

para.heading: When prior notice not required.
para.text: A violation notice or order is not a prerequisite to enforcement action in the following situations:
when seeking a temporary restraining order or injunction in an emergency,
when seeking equitable relief for a pattern or practice of noncompliance,
for work being done without a permit or in violation of a stop-work order,
for a violation that remains unabated after a prior prosecution for that violation,

for a prepayable criminal citation that is issued under City Code Article 19, Subtitle 71 {"Special Enforcement Officers"} and for which prior notice is waived under Article 19, § 71-2 {"Prepayable criminal citations"},
for an environmental citation that is issued under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"},
for occupying or causing to be occupied a building that is subject to a violation notice issued under § 116 {"Unsafe Structures"} or § 120 {"Condemnation Proceedings"}, and
in any other case specifically authorized by this Code.

para.heading: Violation a misdemeanor.
para.text: A person is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to the penalties specified in this § 114.4, if the person:
violates a provision of this Code,
fails to comply with any requirement of this Code or of a {rule,} regulation, order, decision, permit, or notice issued under this Code, or

constructs, alters, adds to, repairs, rehabilitates, demolishes, moves, locates, uses, occupies, or maintains any structure, premises, land, or equipment in violation of an approved plan or directive of the Building Official or of a permit or certificate issued under this Code.

para.heading: Notice required.
para.text: Except as otherwise specifically authorized by law, criminal proceedings may not be initiated unless the Building Official issues a notice of violation and allows a period within which to abate the violation.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: If a violation is not discontinued, abated, or complied with within 14 days from the issuance of a violation notice, each day thereafter that a violation continues is a separate offense. Proof that a violation exists on any date after issuance of a violation notice is prima facie evidence that the violation has continued unabated throughout the intervening period.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: The penalty for each offense is a fine of not more than $500.

para.heading: Civil penalties and costs.
para.text: In equity proceedings instituted under this Code:
a violation for which equitable relief is sought is subject to a civil fine of not more than $500 for each day that the violation continues unabated,

the defendant is liable for the plaintiff's enforcement costs and reasonable attorneys' fees, at the rate established by the Court of Appeals, whether or not the attorney is a salaried employee of the plaintiff, and
judgment may be sought for outstanding liens imposed by the City on property subject to the proceeding and owned by the defendant.

para.heading: Additional legal action.
para.text: The imposition of penalties does not preclude the City Solicitor from instituting appropriate legal proceedings to:
prevent unlawful construction,
restrain, correct, or abate a violation,
prevent illegal occupancy of a structure or premises, or
stop an illegal act, conduct, business, or use of a structure on or about any premises.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This § 114.11 applies whenever the Building Official finds that an owner, an owner's agent, a contractor, or an architect, engineer, or other design professional:

has violated a provision of this Code, of a permit, or of the rules and regulations of any department or agency of the City in connection with the construction, alteration, addition, repair, rehabilitation, demolition, moving, location, use, occupancy, or maintenance of any structure, premises, land, or equipment, or
has failed to pay any outstanding citation issued or fee imposed under this Code.

para.heading: Actions authorized.
para.text: In any situation described in § 114.11.1, the Building Official may:
revoke, without prior notice, any existing permit that has been granted:
to the owner, the owner's agent, the contractor, or the architect, engineer, or other design professional, or
for work in connection with which the design professional is employed, and
refuse to grant, for a period of up to 5 years, any further permits:
to the owner, the owner's agent, the contractor, or the architect, engineer, or other design professional,
for work in connection with which the design professional is employed, or
for work on the property with respect to which the violation occurred.

para.heading: Work without permit.
para.text: Any person who does work without a permit, outside or beyond the scope of a permit, or in a manner inconsistent with plans or drawings approved as part of a permit application:
is in violation of this Code and subject to enforcement action without notice,
must immediately stop any work in progress,
must obtain a permit, paying all associated fees and penalties, whether the work is in progress or completed, and
must restore the structure to its original condition, unless:
the work otherwise conforms to the relevant requirements of law, and
the Building Official, in his or her discretion, allows the work to remain or continue.

para.heading: Responsibility of owners and operators.
para.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided in § 114.21.1, the owner and the operator of any property subject to this Code are each:
responsible for compliance with all provisions of this Code in all matters pertaining directly or indirectly to that property, and
liable for all violations of this Code in connection with any land, structure, matter, or thing owned or controlled by them.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Only the owner is responsible for compliance with a provision requiring an owner's signature. Except as specified in § 114.21.2, an owner or operator is not responsible for compliance with a provision of this Code that is specifically designated as the responsibility of the occupant, unless that owner or operator is also an occupant.

para.heading: Secondary liability.
para.text: If, after a notice, order, or citation, a tenant fails to correct a violation of Property Maintenance Code § 305 {"Exterior Sanitary Maintenance – General"} or § 306 {"Exterior Sanitary Maintenance – Trash, Garbage, and Debris"} for which occupants are responsible under Property Maintenance Code § 308 {"Occupants' Sanitary Responsibilities"}, the owner and operator of the property are secondarily liable.

para.heading: Liability – Failure to register property.
para.text: The owner of a property is responsible for exterior sanitary maintenance if:

the owner fails to register or license the property as required by City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, etc."} or Subtitle 5 {"Licensing of Rental Dwellings"}, or
reasonable attempts at telephone contact, using information in a current registration statement, do not lead within 2 business days to current occupant information.

para.heading: Liability – Third environmental citation.
para.text: The owner of a property is responsible for exterior sanitary maintenance if:

within the previous 12 months, two or more environmental citations were issued under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}, for violations of this Code that were the responsibility of an occupant of the property under Property Maintenance Code § 308 {"Occupants Sanitary Responsibilities"}, and
notification of each citation has been sent to the owner by regular mail.

para.heading: Notice to owner, operator.
para.text: Before an owner or operator may be charged under § 114.21.2a {"Secondary liability"}, he or she must be served with a violation notice under § 123.4 {"Violation notices"}. A violation notice under § 123.4 is not necessary to charge an owner under §§ 114.21.2b {"Liability – Failure to Register Property"} or 114.21.2c {"Liability – Third environmental citation"}.

para.heading: Recovery of expenses.
para.text: If an owner or operator incurs expenses in correcting the violation, the owner or operator:
may bring legal action to recover those expenses from the tenant, and
has all the rights and remedies available under the law for nonpayment.

para.heading: Responsibility of others.
para.text: In addition to the owner or operator of the property involved, any other person who violates any provision of this Code is liable for the violation and, on conviction, is subject to all penalties provided in this Code for the violation.

para.heading: Responsibility of transferee.
para.text: This § 114.23 applies whenever any property is transferred by sale, assignment, ground rent lease, or otherwise, with or without consideration ("transfer"). Except as provided in § 114.25 {"Responsibility of mortgagee"}, this § 114.23 does not apply to a mortgagee or to the holder of a note secured by a deed of trust.

para.heading: Duty before transfer.
para.text: Before any transfer of property, the transferee must obtain a copy of a violation report for the property.

para.heading: Primary liability of transferee.
para.text: On transfer of the property, if any violation or condemnation notices lie against the property and are included in the violation report, the transferee:
becomes primarily liable for those notices the same as if the notices had been addressed to the transferee,
must abate the violation, and

is liable in accordance with § 117 {"Emergency and Corrective Measures"} of this Code for any expenses incurred by the City in abating the violation or condemnation notice, if the transferee failed to request a violation report as required by § 114.23.1.

para.heading: Reliance on violation report.
para.text: A transferee is not liable for abatement expenses incurred by the City if, before the transfer, the transferee requested a violation report and the report does not show the violation.

para.heading: Responsibility of officers, directors, etc., of corporations, partnerships, etc.
para.text: Whenever a corporation, joint stock company, partnership, association, limited liability company, or other entity violates any provision of this Code, every officer, director, trustee, partner, member, or agent of that entity who has authorized or done any of the acts constituting the violation, in whole or in part, or who has failed to act or acquiesced in any failure to act constituting the violation, in whole or in part, is individually guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties provided in this § 114.

para.heading: Responsibility of mortgagee.
para.text: A person that acquires an interest in property by way of a mortgage or deed of trust ("lender") is liable to the same extent as an owner/transferee for a violation or condemnation notice pertaining to a vacant unsafe structure, if:
the person with primary responsibility fails to comply with the notice,
the lender has been notified by certified mail of the violation or condemnation notice, and
within 180 days after the receipt of the notice:
ratification of a foreclosure sale of the property has not occurred, or
the lender has not released its mortgage or deed of trust.

para.heading: Bankruptcy toll.
para.text: The 180-day period referred to in § 114.25(3) is tolled by any period during which the lender's right to foreclose is stayed by a pending proceeding under the federal Bankruptcy Code.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: During any enforcement proceeding instituted against a lender under this section, it is a defense that the lender did not have the right to institute foreclosure proceedings.

para.heading: During pendency of foreclosure.
para.text: During the pendency of a foreclosure, the lender is responsible for maintaining the property free from high vegetation, free from accumulation of trash and debris, and otherwise in full compliance with the requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Responsibility of buyer on foreclosure.
para.text: On foreclosure or sale in lieu of foreclosure, the buyer:
acquires ownership responsibility when the sale is ratified, and
takes title subject to any outstanding notices.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: The stop-work order must be in writing and state the reason for the order. It must be posted on the property. On posting, the cited work must immediately cease. Written notice of the stop-work order must be sent by first class and certified mail to the owner of the property involved.

para.heading: Removal, etc., of posted notice.
para.text: Until the Building Official so authorizes, no person may remove, deface, damage, or change any notice, poster, or sign placed under this section on any land, structure, or other object.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Any structure or part of a structure found to be unsafe or unfit for human habitation or other authorized use must be rehabilitated or, as permitted or required by the Building Official, demolished.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: A structure may be unsafe or unfit for human habitation or other authorized use because of:

conditions constituting a fire hazard or conditions of damage, decay, dilapidation, obsolescence, abandonment, vacancy (as described in § 116.4), insanitation, or vermin or rodent infestation that constitute a hazard to the health, welfare, or safety of occupants or the public,

lack of sanitation, illumination, ventilation, heating, plumbing, exitways, fire protection, utilities, or other facilities adequate to protect the health, welfare, or safety of occupants or the public, or
conditions that are so unsafe, insanitary, overcrowded, improper in use or occupancy, or otherwise dangerous to life, health, welfare, or safety as to create a hazard to occupants or the public.

para.heading: Occupied unsafe structures.
para.text: Whenever the Building Official or the Commissioner of Health finds all or any part of an occupied structure to be unsafe or unfit for human habitation or other authorized use:
either the Building Official or Commissioner of Health may:
post an order requiring the structure or affected part to be vacated, and
take necessary steps to remove occupants who fail or refuse to vacate,
once vacated, the structure or affected part may not be reoccupied until:
it is rehabilitated to comply with all applicable codes and ordinances, and
the Building Official has issued an occupancy permit, and
pending rehabilitation, the structure must be kept secure against casual entry and the premises kept free of occupants, litter, high grass, and weeds.

para.heading: Temporarily unoccupied structures.
para.text: Any structure or part of a structure that has been left unoccupied without removing appliances or portable equipment or furniture and without disconnecting utility service must be safeguarded by closing and securely locking all windows, doors, and other openings.

para.heading: Vacant structures.
para.text: Every vacant structure, as defined in this § 116.4, is declared to be a fire hazard and a nuisance per se, and must be safeguarded and otherwise maintained as required in this § 116.4.

para.heading: General.
para.text: In this § 116.4, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Vacant structure.
para.text: "Vacant structure" means a structure or distinguishable part of a structure that is:
unoccupied, and
either:
unsafe or unfit for human habitation or other authorized use, or
a nuisance property.

para.heading: Nuisance property.
para.text: "Nuisance property" means:

an unoccupied structure for which 2 or more final, non-appealable Building Code, Fire Code, or Property Maintenance Code violations remained unabated for 10 days or more beyond the date by which the violation notice, citation, or order required the violation to be corrected; or
