A written agreement is in place between owners/operators of the splash pad and the adjoining local businesses or other organizations that allows splash pad patrons access to bathroom facilities located in the adjoining local businesses or other organizations.

para.heading: Flood resistance.
para.text: For structures in a flood hazard area, exterior walls extending below the flood elevation should comply with the requirements of the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: General discharge requirements.
para.text: Gutters, downspouts, and leaders must be provided on all buildings to properly collect, conduct, and discharge the water from their roofs into a storm drain or into the driveway of an alley, street, or other public way. No water from any building may be discharged so as to run or flow over any sidewalk, footway, or any adjoining property, except from window sills, copings, or cornices that project no more than 1 foot (305 mm).

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This § 1502.5 does not apply to:

roofs, cornices, copings, or other similar projections that are less than 5 feet (1.52 m), measured horizontally in the line of flow, as long as the water from them is not discharged on any sidewalk, footway, or adjoining property, or
awnings or marquees that discharge off the outer edge.

para.heading: Methods.
para.text: Drainage must be conveyed in 1 of the following methods.

para.heading: Method 1.
para.text: Drainage may be discharged by piping to a storm drain, to the street or alley, or to an approved water course. The installation of piping, connections to storm drains, etc., must be made in accordance with the plumbing regulations of Chapter 29 {"Plumbing Systems"} of this Code. Any continuous discharge of drainage water into the public right-of-way of such a volume and frequency as to cause ponding or icing is prohibited and must be conveyed to the nearest public storm water drain or inlet through underground piping.

para.heading: Method 2.
para.text: Drainage may be discharged not less than 10 feet (3.05 m) from the building, from other buildings, or from any adjacent property line, as long as the discharge is in such a manner as not to allow drainage to cross adjacent property lines or sidewalks.

para.heading: Individual downspouts.
para.text: Gutters of buildings on adjoining properties may not be connected with common downspouts or leaders, but each building must have individual downspouts or leaders on its own property. If a building is more than 4 stories or 50 feet (15.24 m) high, its leader and downspouts must be inside the building's exterior walls.

para.heading: Relief scuppers.
para.text: Roofs with interior roof drains and enclosed by parapet walls that will impound water must be provided with relief scuppers placed in the parapet wall not more than 6 inches (152 mm) above the roof level. The openings of these relief scuppers must be at least 6 inches (152 mm) in diameter. Each 6-inch (152-mm) diameter relief scupper opening may only serve a roof area of not more than 1,000 square feet (92.9 square meters).

para.heading: Internal relief drains.
para.text: Internal relief drains may be used instead of relief scuppers. Internal relief drains must be independent of the required roof drains.

para.heading: Reflectance.
para.text: Roof Coverings over conditioned spaces on low-slope roofs (roof slope < 2:12) on newly constructed buildings and additions to existing buildings shall have a minimum 3-year-aged solar reflective index of 78, as determined by the Cool Roof Rating Council.
Exceptions:
An addition to a roof that supports living vegetation and includes a synthetic, high quality waterproof membrane, drainage layer, soil layer, and lightweight medium plants.
Roof areas used as outdoor recreation space by the occupants of the building.
An area including and adjacent to rooftop photovoltaic and solar thermal equipment, totaling not more than 3 times the area that is covered with photovoltaic and solar thermal equipment.
Limited roof areas as determined by regulations promulgated by the Department of Housing & Community Development.
A roof, the area of which is less than 3% of the gross floor area of the building.

para.heading: Conflicts.
para.text: In the event of a conflict between § 1504.10 of this Code and City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"} prevails.

para.heading: Rooftop decks.
para.text: Rooftop decks must comply with this § 1511.9 and with Chapter 16 {"Structural Design"} of this Code.

para.heading: Materials.
para.text: Rooftop decks must be constructed with approved materials in accordance with Chapters 19 through 26 of this Code.

para.heading: Notice to adjoining owners.
para.text: If a rooftop deck is to be supported by party walls:
the owners of the adjoining properties must be notified in writing, and
evidence of this notice must be submitted with the construction documents.

para.heading: Construction documents.
para.text: Construction documents for all rooftop decks must:
include dimensional setbacks, and
be signed and sealed by a professional architect or engineer licensed in Maryland.

para.heading: Clearances.
para.text: All rooftop decks must maintain all clearances otherwise required by this Code, including Chapter 8 {"Chimneys and Vents"} of the International Mechanical Code and § 230.24 {"Clearances"} of the National Electrical Code.

para.heading: Height.
para.text: No rooftop deck may be raised more than 2 feet (0.61 m) above the plane that is midway between the lowest and the highest points of the roof surface supporting the rooftop deck.

para.heading: Setbacks.
para.text: A rooftop deck must comply with:
the minimum setbacks specified in § 1511.9.6.1, and
any greater or additional setback requirements established by or under the Baltimore City Zoning Code and any applicable Urban Renewal Plan.

para.heading: Minimum setbacks.
para.text: A rooftop deck must comply with the following minimum setbacks:

tr.td: 8 feet (2.44 m) from face of building wall
Mansard Roof (steeply pitched front slope followed by flat roof) –

para.heading: General.
para.text: Exception: Construction documents for buildings constructed in accordance with the conventional light-frame construction provisions of § 2308 must indicate the following structural design information:
Flood design data, if located in a flood hazard area.

para.heading: Flood design data.
para.text: For structures located in whole or in part in a flood hazard area, the documentation pertaining to design, if required by the Floodplain Management Code, must be included, and the following information, referenced to the datum on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), must be shown, regardless of whether flood loads govern the design of the structure:
In flood hazard areas not subject to high-velocity wave action, the elevation of the proposed lowest floor.
In flood hazard areas not subject to high-velocity wave action, the elevation to which any nonresidential building will be dry floodproofed.
In flood hazard areas subject to high-velocity wave action, the proposed elevation of the bottom of the lowest horizontal structural member of the lowest floor, including the basement.
Any other documentation required by the Flood Management Code.

para.heading: Ordinary roofs, awnings, and canopies.
para.text: Ordinary flat, pitched, and curved roofs, and awnings and canopies other than opf fabric construction supported by a skeleton structure, must be designed for the following minimum live loads:

tr.td: Live Load (pounds/square foot of horizontal projection)
Rise 4" (102 mm) per foot to less than 12" (305 mm) per foot
Rise 12" (305 mm) per foot and greater
Arch or dome with rise less than 1/8 of span
Arch or dome with rise 1/8 of span to less than 3/8 of span
Arch or dome with rise 3/8 of span or greater

section.heading: Flood Loads
section.text: {Note: For the establishment of Regulated Flood Hazard Areas and the special regulations and limitations governing development within those areas, see the Floodplain Management Code, City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, Division I {"Floodplain Management"}.}

para.heading: General.
para.text: Any permit application for underpinning foundation walls must include the following:
structural drawings that:
indicate the exact sequence of operation, and
are signed and sealed by an architect or engineer licensed to practice in this State,
a statement of responsibility from the architect or engineer of record that the architect or engineer agrees:

to schedule and attend, before an underpinning permit can be issued, an in-office meeting with the Building Official's plans examining office, at which meeting the architect or engineer and the contractor must be present and review requirements with staff,
to complete, sign, and return to the plans examining office the office's inspections and safeguards checklist,
to coordinate and schedule a pre-inspection on-site meeting before any underpinning work starts,
to ensure that the work will conform to the structural drawings and all applicable codes,
to periodically inspect the work,
to immediately report to the Building Official any construction problems or irregularities,
to provide inspection reports with work activity photographs to the city inspector, and
within 10 days after the work is completed, to submit a certification of completion, and
if the underpinning is to be done on a party wall, evidence that the notice required by § 1804.2.2 was given.

para.heading: Party walls.
para.text: If the underpinning is to be done on a party wall, the applicant must give written notice of the proposed underpinning to the owners of all adjoining properties, with a copy to the Building Official. This notice must be given at least 10 days before an application for the underpinning permit is filed.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The written notice must:
indicate the intent to underpin the structure,
specify:
the earliest date (to be at least 10 days after the notice is served) when the underpinning permit is expected to be filed, and
the earliest date when the work is expected to begin,
identify the contractor scheduled to perform the underpinning and the contractor's emergency contact information, including cell phone number and email address,
identify the architect or engineer who signed and sealed the plans and will certify the underpinning,
include a copy of all documents that are relevant to the adjoining property and are to be filed for the permit, and
include the following statement:

"The Baltimore City Building, Fire, and Related Codes provides that any person aggrieved by a permit issued by the Building Official may apply for a review of that decision. If you would like to challenge the issuance of this underpinning permit, your request must:
be in writing;
be made before or within 10 days after issuance of the permit;
set forth in full the reasons for review; and
either be:
mailed by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the Deputy Commissioner of Permits and Code Enforcement at 417 E. Fayette Street, 3rd Floor, Baltimore, Maryland, 21202; or
delivered to that Deputy Commissioner's office and stamped received by the office."

para.heading: Service of notice.
para.text: The notice must be:
personally served on the owner of the adjoining property, or
sent both by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, and by first class mail to the owner at:
the adjoining property's mailing address, and
if different, the owner's mailing address recorded in the property's tax records.

para.heading: Grading and fill in flood hazard areas.
para.text: In flood hazard areas, grading or fill may not be approved unless it meets the requirements of the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: Flood hazard areas.
para.text: For structures in a flood hazard area, the finished ground level of an under-floor space, such as a crawl space, must meet the requirements of the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: Frost protection.
para.text: Except where otherwise protected from frost, foundation walls, piers, and other permanent supports of buildings and structures must be protected by one or more of the following methods:
extending 30" below grade,
constructing in accordance with ASCE 32, or
erecting on solid rock.

section.heading: Safety Glazing
section.reason: As in IBC, subject to the following Note
section.text: {MBPS Modification — The requirements for safety glazing contained in State Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 4, are in addition to those contained in § 2406 of the IBC. In the event of a conflict between the Maryland Code and the IBC, the Maryland Code prevails.}

container.heading: Gypsum Board, Gypsum Panel Products, and Plaster

para.heading: Location.
para.text: Where § 705 {"Exterior Walls"} of this Code requires exterior wall openings to be protected, a roof panel or unit may not be installed within 4 feet (1219 mm) of the exterior wall.

para.heading: Location.
para.text: Where § 705 {"Exterior Walls"} of this Code requires exterior wall openings to be protected, a skylight may not be installed within 4 feet (1219 mm) of the exterior wall.

para.heading: Combinations of roof panels and skylights.

container.heading: Electrical
container.text: {MBPS Modification – The subject matter of this Chapter is not within the scope of the Maryland Building Performance Standards. See the Baltimore City Electrical Code in Part III {"Electrical"} of this Article, and the National Electrical Code as adopted and enforced by the State Fire Marshall under State Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 6.}

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This Chapter governs the electrical components, equipment, and systems used in structures covered by this Code. Electrical components, equipment, and systems must be designed and constructed in accordance with the National Electrical Code ("NEC").

para.heading: Electric equipment standards.
para.text: Only electrical materials, appliances, or equipment approved by the Building Official may be installed. The Building Official must approve all materials, appliances, and equipment that are listed and labeled by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Incorporated, or by any other independent testing organization that the Building Official approves, except for any materials, appliances, or equipment that other provisions of this Code preclude from being installed. In investigating new materials, appliances, and equipment, the Building Official must consider the factors listed in NEC § 110.3 {"Examination, Identification, Installation, and Use of Equipment"}.

para.heading: Applications.
para.text: The application for an electrical permit must bear the name and address of the insured, licensed electrician responsible for all work to be done under the permit.

para.heading: Permits for maintenance work.
para.text: Any person who employs 1 or more licensed maintenance electricians or licensed master electricians for maintenance of approved installations in or on a structure or premises owned or operated by the person must:
obtain individual permits for the maintenance work, or
apply for and obtain a semiannual permit for all maintenance work to be performed by these licensed electricians.

para.heading: Semiannual records.
para.text: The person to whom a semiannual permit is issued must keep a detailed record of all maintenance work done under the permit. These records must be:
available at all times for inspection by the Building Official, or
if the Building Official so specifies, filed with the Building Official.

para.heading: Certificates.
para.text: An electrical certificate is required before electric service may be energized in any structure. On request and payment of the required fee, the Building Official will issue an
electrical certificate to the owner of any electrical installation that conforms to the requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Periodic inspections for places of assembly.
para.text: In any place of public assembly for which an inspection registration permit is required, the Building Official must make periodic inspections of the electric wiring, appliances, and equipment.

para.heading: Conformance required.
para.text: Any existing electrical equipment, appliance, wiring, or other electrical work in service that does not comply with this Code and creates a menace to life or property must, as directed in writing by the Building Official:
be made to conform to the requirements of this Code, or
be put out of service and either sealed or removed.

para.heading: Permit required.
para.text: Unless specifically excepted by this Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, no electrical work may be undertaken before the Building Official has issued a permit for that work.

para.heading: To whom issued.
para.text: A permit may be issued only:
to a master electrician licensed to do business in the City,
to a master restricted electrician licensed to do business in the City,
to a restricted electrician licensed to do business in the City, or
to a maintenance electrician licensed to do business in the City.

para.heading: Licenses and supervision required.
para.text: No person may provide electrical services or otherwise engage in any electrical work unless the person:
is licensed to do so in accordance with State law, and
is insured or working under the direct supervision of an insured, licensed electrician.

container.heading: Mechanical Systems
container.text: {MBPS Modification – The subject matter of this Chapter is not within the scope of the Maryland Building Performance Standards. See the Fuel Gas Code and Mechanical Code in Parts IV and V of this Article, and the mechanical code adopted under State Business Regulation Article § 9A-205.}

para.heading: Scope – General.
para.text: Mechanical appliances, equipment, and systems must be constructed. installed, and maintained in accordance with:
the International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part V of this Code, and
the International Fuel Gas Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part IV of this Code.

para.heading: Scope – Chimneys, fireplaces, barbecues.
para.text: Masonry chimneys, fireplaces, and barbecues must comply with:
Chapter 21 {"Masonry"} of this Code, and
the International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part V of this Code.

para.heading: Permit required.
para.text: Unless specifically excepted by this Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, no heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration ("HVACR") work may be undertaken before the Building Official has issued a permit for that work.

para.heading: Applications.
para.text: The application for an HVACR work permit must bear the name and address of the insured, licensed HVACR contractor responsible for all work to be done under the permit.

para.heading: To whom issued.
para.text: A permit may be issued only:
to a master HVACR contractor licensed to do business in the City,
to a master restricted HVACR contractor licensed to do business in the City,
to a limited HVACR contractor licensed to do business in the City,
to a journeyman HVACR contractor licensed to do business in the City, or
to a journeyman restricted HVACR contractor licensed to do business in the City.

para.heading: Licenses and supervision required.
para.text: No person may provide HVACR services or otherwise engage in any HVACR work unless the person:
is licensed to do so in accordance with State law, and
is insured or working under the direct supervision of an insured, licensed HVACR contractor.

container.heading: Plumbing Systems
container.text: {MBPS Modification – The subject matter of this Chapter is not within the scope of the Maryland Building Performance Standards. See the Plumbing Code in Part VI of this Article, and the plumbing code adopted under State Business and Occupation Article, Title 12.}

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The erection, installation, alteration, repairs, relocation, replacement, use, or maintenance of or addition to plumbing equipment and systems are governed by:
this Chapter,
the International Plumbing Code (2021 Edition) (the "IPC"), as modified by Part VI of this Code; and
for private sewage disposal systems, COMAR 26.04.02 {"Sewage Disposal and Certain Water Systems..."}.

para.heading: "Plumbing regulations".
para.text: Together, this Chapter 29 and the IPC are referred to in this Code as "plumbing regulations".

para.heading: Single-user toilet facility and bathing room fixture.
Family or assisted-use toilet and bath fixtures.
para.text: Fixtures located within accessible family or assisted-use toilet and bathing rooms required by the Maryland Accessibility Code (COMAR 09.12.53) are permitted to be included in the number of required fixtures for either the male or female occupants in assembly and mercantile occupancies.

para.heading: Signage.
para.text: Required public facilities must be provided with signs that designate the sex, as required by § 2902.2. Signs must be readily visible and located near the entrance to each toilet facility. Signs for accessible toilet facilities must comply with the Maryland Accessibility Code (COMAR 09.12.53).

para.heading: Gender-inclusive signage.
para.text: If separate facilities for each sex are not required, as permitted by the exceptions to § 2902.2 {"Separate facilities”} of this Code, then Article 15, § 43-3 {"Requirement for single-user restrooms”} of the City Code mandates that a public single-user restroom in a commercial or industrial establishment, a place of public accommodation, or a City-owned or -occupied building shall be:
made available for use by individuals of any gender, and
identified with gender-inclusive signage.

{Editor's Note: But see City Code Article 15, Subtitle 43 {"Public Restrooms"}, which requires the use of "gender-inclusive signage" to identify any "public single-use restroom" in a commercial or industrial establishment, a place of public accommodation, or a City-owned or -occupied building.}

para.heading: Permit required.
para.text: Unless specifically excepted by these plumbing regulations, no plumbing work may be undertaken before the Building Official has issued a permit for that work.

para.heading: Applications.
para.text: The application for a plumbing work permit must bear the name and address of the insured, licensed master plumber responsible for all work to be done under the permit.

para.heading: To whom issued.
para.text: A permit may be issued only:
to a master plumber licensed to do business in the City,
to a master gas fitter licensed to do business in the City, or
for on-site utility facilities, to an on-site utility contractor licensed to do business in the City.

para.heading: Insurance.
para.text: The Building Official may not issue a permit to any master plumber unless the master plumber has provided the Building Official with certification of insurance, as required by State law.

para.heading: Emergency work.
para.text: When emergency work needs to be done to rectify a possible health hazard or other hazardous condition, the work may be undertaken, even before a permit is issued, by:
a master plumber, or
within the scope of his or her license:
an on-site utility contractor, or
a gas fitter.

para.heading: Notice and subsequent permit.
para.text: A master plumber, contractor, or gas fitter who performs emergency work under this section must:
promptly notify the proper City authorities of the emergency, and
within a reasonable time, obtain a permit for the work.

para.heading: Licenses and supervision required.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person may provide plumbing services or otherwise engage in any plumbing work unless:
the person is licensed to do so in accordance with State law, and
the services and work are done by or under the direct supervision of an insured, licensed master plumber.

para.heading: On-site utilities work.
para.text: On-site utility work, as defined in City Code Article 13, § 18-1, may be done by or under the direct supervision of an on-site utility contractor licensed by the City.

para.heading: Gas-fitting work.
para.text: A licensed gas fitter may perform any gas-fitting work that falls within the scope of his or her license.

para.heading: Limits on plumber's, etc., liability.
para.text: The liability of the surety on any bond given under this Chapter and the liability of any master plumber or on-site utility contractor for materials furnished or work done under this Code does not extend to defects in materials or workmanship discovered more than 1 year after completion of the work.

para.heading: Plumber's, etc., responsibility for certain defects.
para.text: The surety and the master plumber or on-site utility contractor are responsible to the City to correct all defects that are discovered during the 1-year period after completion of the work and about which they were promptly notified in writing.

para.heading: Owner remains responsible.
para.text: Notwithstanding the limited liabilities of the surety and the master plumber or on-site utility contractor, the owner of the property is responsible at all times to the City to correct any defects in the plumbing installations in or on his or her property.

para.heading: Use of license by others prohibited.
para.text: A master plumber, on-site utility contractor, or gas fitter may not allow his or her name to be used by any other person for obtaining permits or for doing business or work under his or her license.

container.heading: Elevators and Conveying Systems
container.text: {MBPS Modification – Note to Chapter 30: The provisions of Chapter 30 of the IBC relate to elevators and conveying systems and are in addition to and not instead of the requirements contained in State Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 8. In the event of a conflict between the Maryland Code and the IBC, the Maryland Code prevails.}

para.heading: Emergency elevator communication systems for the deaf, hard of hearing, and speech impaired.
para.text: An emergency two-way communication system shall be provided that:
is a visual, text-based, and video-based 24/7 live interactive system,
is fully accessible by the deaf, hard of hearing, and speech impaired, and includes voice-only options for hearing individuals,
has the ability to communicate with emergency personnel utilizing existing video conferencing technology, chat/text software or other approved technology, and
complies with all applicable requirements of the Maryland Accessibility Code (COMAR 09.12.53).

para.heading: Referenced standards.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided for in this Code, the design, construction, installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of elevators, conveying systems, and their components conform to ASME A17.1/CSA B44, ASME A17.7/CSA B44.7, ASME A90.1, ASME B20.1, ANSI MH29.1, ALI ALCTV, and, for construction in flood hazard areas, ASCE 24.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Awnings and canopies must comply with the requirements of:
this section,
other applicable sections of this article, and
the laws{, rules,} and regulations governing minor privilege permits.

para.heading: Aircraft warning lights.
para.text: Radio and television towers must be equipped with aircraft warning lights that comply with Federal Aviation Administration requirements.

section.heading: Swimming Pools, Spas, and Hot Tubs

para.heading: General.
para.text: Swimming pools, spas, and hot tubs must comply with the requirements of:
the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code {Part XII of this article},
other applicable sections of this article,
all {rules and} regulations of the Baltimore City Health Department, and
all location and other applicable provisions of the Baltimore City Zoning Code.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Structures with glazed surfaces that are used for horticulture are classified as greenhouses. These structures must be independent and separated from other buildings on the same lot. All greenhouses must conform to the requirements of this Code for exits and for materials.

para.heading: Commercial greenhouses.
para.text: Commercial greenhouses are classified as Group S-2, Low Hazard Storage Buildings, and must comply with § 503 {"General Building Height and Area Limitations"} and Tables 601 {"Fire-Resistant Rating Requirements for Building Elements"} and 602 {"Fire-Resistant Rating Requirements for Exterior Walls"} of this Code.

para.heading: Residential greenhouses.
para.text: Greenhouses that are located on a lot zoned for residential use are classified as Group U, Utility and Miscellaneous Structures.

para.heading: Height.
para.text: Residential greenhouses may not exceed 20 feet (6.10 m) above grade.

para.heading: Size.
para.text: The floor area of a residential greenhouse must conform to the requirements of the Baltimore City Zoning Code.

para.heading: Location.
para.text: Residential greenhouses must be located at least 36 inches (914 mm) from any property line or other structure.

para.heading: Accessibility.
para.text: Greenhouses must be accessible in accordance with the Maryland Accessibility Code, COMAR 09.12.53.

para.heading: Structural design.
para.text: Greenhouses must comply with the structural design requirements for greenhouses in Chapter 16 {"Structural Design"} of this Code.

para.heading: Glass and glazing.
para.text: Glass and glazing used in greenhouses must comply with § 2405 {"Sloped Glazing and Skylights"} of this Code.

para.heading: Light-transmitting plastics.
para.text: Light-transmitting plastics are permitted in lieu of plain glass in greenhouses and must comply with § 2606 "Light-Transmitting Plastics"} of this Code.

para.heading: Membrane structures.
para.text: Greenhouses that are membrane structures must comply with § 3102 {"Membrane Structures"} of this Code.

para.heading: Plastic film.
para.text: Plastic films used in greenhouses must comply with § 3102.3 {"Type of construction"} of this Code.

section.heading: Parking Lots, Driveways, and Other Paved Surfaces

para.heading: Section inapplicable to special-event parking.
para.text: This § 3116 does not apply to special-event parking lots operating under and in compliance with City Code Article 15, Subtitle 13 {"Parking facilities – Special-Event Parking Lots"} as long as the lot complies with all other requirements applicable to the lot's principal occupancy, use, or structure.

para.heading: Driveway entrances.
para.text: All driveway entrances located on a public right-of-way must be constructed in accordance with the rules, regulations, and permit requirements of the Department of Transportation.

para.heading: Surface paving.
para.text: Parking lots, parking pads, driveways, and private roads must be paved with asphalt, brick, concrete, macadam, or stone block. Permeable paving systems may be utilized in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Department of Public Works. All paving must be able to support the design loads for the proposed vehicular traffic.

para.heading: Parking spaces.
para.text: The size, layout, and arrangement of parking spaces must comply with:
the Baltimore City Zoning Code,
the Maryland State Accessability Code, and
the rules and regulations of the City Planning Commission.

para.heading: Curbs or bumpers.
para.text: Curbs or bumpers must be installed for all parking spaces. Each curb or bumper must be:
made of concrete, wood, or an approved metal wheel stop,
at least 6 inches (152 mm) high and 8 inches (203 mm) wide,
securely fixed in place, and
located:
at least 4 feet (1.22 m) from the parking lot perimeter, or
for parking spaces that are parallel to the perimeter of the parking lot, at least 2 feet (0.61 m) from the perimeter.

para.heading: Surface drainage.
para.text: Storm drainage off paved surface areas, such as parking lots, playgrounds, and plazas, must be properly conveyed to paved alleys, paved streets, or other approved water courses.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: No drainage may be discharged:
so as to run or flow over any sidewalk or footway, except at a driveway with a depressed curb, or
across any adjoining property.

para.heading: Methods.
para.text: Drainage must be piped to a storm drain, to the street or alley, to a paved swale, or to another approved water course. The installation of piping, connections to storm drains, etc., must be made in accordance with the plumbing regulations of Chapter 29 {"Plumbing Systems"} of this Code.

para.heading: General.
para.text: All piers, marinas, and related structures constructed or demolished along the shoreline of the City must comply with the requirements of this § 3117, in addition to all other applicable provisions of this Code.

para.heading: Plans and specifications.
para.text: All proposed work for piers and marinas requires plans and specifications that illustrate, describe, and specify the proposed work in sufficient detail and clarity.

para.heading: Approvals.
para.text: Before a building permit may be issued for the construction or demolition of a pier, marina, or related structure, the work must be approved by:
the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Baltimore District),
the State of Maryland,
the Division of Construction and Buildings Inspection,
the Baltimore City Fire Department,
the Baltimore City Department of Transportation, and
the Baltimore City Department of Public Works.

para.heading: Design.
para.text: All shoreline and offshore free-standing piers, with or without buildings, must be designed in accordance with:
the design manuals of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and
the requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Structural design for piers.
para.text: Minimum live load requirements are as follows:
for static or fixed piers or marinas for light duty uses, 60 pounds per square foot, and
for heavy duty live loads and for structures constructed on piers, as required by Chapter 16 {"Structural Design"} of this Code.

para.heading: Structures on piers.
para.text: Every structure that is constructed on a pier, wharf, dock, bulkhead, breakwater, piles, or other similar structure must comply with this § 3117 and all other applicable provisions of this Code and other law.

para.heading: Location.
para.text: A fence may be built only on the property of the owner of the fence. However, if the owners of adjoining property agree to build a fence on the property line between them, they may do so if they both submit, with the application for the permit, a written statement of their agreement.

para.heading: Height.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this § 3118.2, the height of a fence may not exceed 42 inches (1067 mm), measured on the high side.

para.heading: Enclosing dwellings.
para.text: Fences enclosing dwellings may be as high as, but may not exceed, 6 feet (1.83 m) if located in side or rear yards.

para.heading: Enclosing certain other buildings.
para.text: Fences enclosing buildings used for public assembly, private assembly, institutions, offices, commercial storage, or industrial occupancies may be as high as, but may not exceed, 8 feet (2.44 m).

para.heading: Special purposes.
para.text: For special purposes like protection around dangerous places, highly hazardous operations, in conjunction with electric security, or protection around athletic fields, and in similar cases where a high fence is necessary for the safety of the public, fences may be higher than 8 feet (2.44 m) to the extent specially authorized by the Building Official.

para.heading: Construction.
para.text: Fences may be built of any material or construction that is permitted in this Code for exposed structures. However, all fences must be designed and constructed, in accordance with the applicable structural provisions of this Code, to resist from any direction a horizontal force of 20 pounds per square foot, applied normal to and over either the gross area of the fence or the net area of the fence plus 50% of the gross area, whichever is less.

para.heading: Wood fences.
para.text: The posts for wood fences must be:
locust, heart cedar, or any other wood that will resist decay underground,
any wood that has been treated in accordance with this Code, or
any good timber set in concrete.

para.heading: Wire fences.
para.text: Wire fences must be constructed with wire mesh substantially fabricated and constructed so as to resist a nominal horizontal load of 500 pounds without deflecting more than 6 inches (152 mm). The posts for wire fences must be metal posts set in concrete, properly designed masonry posts, or wood posts of the type required for wood fences.

para.heading: Metal fences.
para.text: Metal fences must be of a substantial design and construction approved by the Building Official. The posts for metal fences must be concrete, masonry, or metal set in concrete or masonry.

para.heading: Masonry fences.
para.text: Masonry fences must be of reinforced concrete or other masonry and must be designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements governing reinforced concrete or freestanding masonry walls. All masonry fences must extend at least 2 feet (0.61 m) into the ground.

para.heading: Combination fences.
para.text: Fences that consist of 2 or more kinds of materials may be built as long as all applicable requirements of this Code for those materials and construction are met. The total aggregate height of a combination fence must be used in determining the height limitations for that fence.

para.heading: Sharp points, projections, etc.
para.text: No fence may have any projecting sharp points, jagged edges, or other projections that can injure persons or animals coming in contact with the fence.

para.heading: Fence tops.
para.text: No fence less than 3 feet 6 inches (1.07 m) high may have any sharp pickets or vertical pointed objects at the top. Barbed wire or other approved retarding material or construction may be placed on the top of any fence that is more than 6 feet 9 inches (2.06 m) high, unless the barbed wire or other retarding material will create a highly hazardous condition.

para.heading: Razor wire.
para.text: Razor wire may not be used anywhere in any fence.

para.heading: Electric security fences.
para.text: An electric security fence is permitted:
only in a C-3, C-4, or Industrial Zoning District, as identified in City Code Article 32 {"Zoning"}; and
only as long as long as the fence:
does not abut any residentially zoned parcel; and
is installed in conjunction with an exterior, non-electric barrier fence.

para.heading: Maintenance.
para.text: Every fence must be maintained in good repair by its owner. The Building Official may determine the sufficiency of any fence and the amount and character of repairs required to make it safe.

para.heading: Nonconforming fences.
para.text: Any existing fence that was compliant when erected but does not comply with the requirements of this § 3118 is permitted to continue to exist and be repaired at any time, unless the fence has deteriorated more than 50%. All nonconforming fences that have deteriorated more than 50% or beyond repair must be removed or reconstructed in accordance with the requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Aircraft warning lights.
para.text: Radio and television antennas located on a high rise building or on a high terrain feature must comply with Federal Aviation Administration requirements for aircraft warning lights.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Lightning protection for buildings and structures must comply with NFPA 780.

para.heading: Other laws.
para.text: This Chapter does not permit anything that is otherwise prohibited or regulated by any law governing the use of public property.

para.heading: Permission needed for encroachments.
para.text: No person may use, encroach on, or connect to any street, highway, alley, or other public right-of-way for any purpose unless that person first obtains permission to do so by:
an ordinance of the Mayor and City Council,
a minor privilege permit issued by or under the authority of the Board of Estimates, or
an appropriate permit issued by the Department of Transportation.

para.heading: Drainage generally.
para.text: Drainage may not be discharged from private property on to the public right-of-way except through piping to a storm drain, to a street or alley, or to some other water course approved by the Department of Public Works. Drainage may not be discharged to flow over the surface of any public sidewalk.

para.heading: Encroachment above grade and below 8' in height.
Steps.
para.text: Steps may not project more than any 1 or another of the following distances:
1/4 of the width of a public sidewalk on which the steps are located,
4 feet (1219 mm) into a public sidewalk, or
any distance that leaves a clear public sidewalk of less than 4 feet (1219 mm).

para.heading: Unauthorized encroachment.
para.text: In this § 3202.5, "unauthorized encroachment" means any building, structure, projection, object, or other thing that has been placed, constructed, or installed on or connected to a public right-of-way without appropriate permission, as outlined in § 3201.3.1 {"Permission needed..."}.

para.heading: Removal of unauthorized encroachments.
para.text: On notice from the Building Official or the Director of Transportation, the owner of any unauthorized encroachment must immediately:
remove the encroachment, or
obtain appropriate permission for its continuation.

para.heading: Prohibited hours.
para.text: No site work, demolition work, pile driving work, or construction work is permitted between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., if that work or any part of a premises in or on which the work is to be done is within 300 feet (91.44 m) of any dwelling.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This § 3301.3 does not apply to an emergency operation that has been specifically approved by the Building Official.

para.heading: Remodeling and additions.
para.text: Required exits, existing structural elements, fire protection devices, and sanitary safeguards must be maintained at all times during remodeling, alterations, repairs, or additions to any building or structure.
When these required elements or devices are themselves being remodeled, altered, or repaired, adequate substitute provisions must be made.
These requirements do not apply if the existing building is not occupied.

para.heading: Waste and debris.
para.text: All sites for new construction or for remodeling, alterations, repairs, or additions, and all abutting sidewalks, gutters, and alleys, must be properly maintained and kept free of accumulated trash, garbage, waste, or debris, including construction waste or debris, and of any object or condition that constitutes a nuisance. Removal of all trash, garbage, waste, and debris must be done in a manner that prevents injury or damage to persons, adjoining properties, and public rights-of-way.

para.heading: Filling required.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this § 3303.4, where a structure has been demolished or removed, the vacant area must be filled with approved material and maintained to the existing grade or otherwise in accordance with City law and seeded.

para.heading: Cellar floors.
para.text: All basement and cellar floors must be removed or completely broken up before any filling materials are used.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: The Building Official may waive the filling requirements of this § 3303.4 for up to 3 months if:
the Building Official receives satisfactory evidence that construction of a new building or structure will begin on the site within 3 months of the demolition or removal, and
the site is protected with barriers that comply with § 3306.5 {"Barriers"}of this Code.

para.heading: Notice to adjoining owners and others.
para.text: A permit to demolish a structure may not be issued unless:
all notices required by §§ 105.9 {"Special requirements for demolition or moving"} and 3307.1 {"Protection required"} of this Code have been given, and
copies of the notices are submitted with the permit application.

para.heading: Demolition contractor's license.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this § 3303.9, no person may engage in the demolition of any structure without first obtaining a demolition contractor's license from the Building Official.

para.heading: Prerequisites.
para.text: Every contractor applying for a new license or for the renewal of a license must:
provide the Building Official with the full name, phone number, address, and (if available) email address of the contractor's business, and
provide the Building Official with a copy of a liability insurance policy that complies with § 3303.10 of this Code.

para.heading: Term; fees.
para.text: A demolition contractor's license expires on December 31 of each year. The license may be renewed annually, on or before December 31, on payment of the renewal fee. The license fees are as set by the Building Official with the approval of the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Change of name or address.
para.text: A licensee must immediately notify the Building Official of any change in the name, phone number, address, or email address of the licensee's business.

para.heading: Use of license by other.
para.text: A licensee may not allow his or her name to be used by another person for the purpose of obtaining permits or for doing any demolition work under the licensee's license.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: The Building Official may waive the requirements of this § 3303.9 if the structure to be demolished is a miscellaneous structure as described in § 312 {"Utility, Miscellaneous Group U"} of this Code.

para.heading: Enforcement.
para.text: A violation notice is not a prerequisite to the enforcement of this § 3303.9 by any appropriate legal proceeding. Penalties will be assessed in accordance with § 114 {"Violations"} of this Code.

para.heading: Debarment on conviction.
para.text: Any person convicted of a violation of this § 3303.9 is, in addition to any other penalty that might be imposed:
prohibited from performing demolition work without first obtaining a new license, and
is ineligible to receive a new license for 1 year.

para.heading: Demolition insurance.
para.text: The licensee must have an insurance policy that complies with the minimum requirements of this § 3303.10.

para.heading: Coverage.
para.text: The policy must provide coverage for all operations for which a permit might be sought. The minimum coverage requirements are:
$500,000 for damages (including damages for care and loss of services) because of bodily injury (including death at any time resulting from bodily injury), per person, per incident,

$1,000,000 for damages (including damages for care and loss of services) because of bodily injury (including death at any time resulting from bodily injury) sustained by more than 1 person per incident, and
$250,000 for injury to or destruction of property of others per incident.

para.heading: Prohibited exclusions.
para.text: The policy may not contain:
any "collapse hazard" exclusion,
any exclusion that would prohibit the contractor from performing the demolition operations in accordance with this Code and the normal procedures of the industry, or
any exclusion that would create an undue risk to the City or to the health, safety, and welfare of the general public.

para.heading: Cancellation.
para.text: The terms of policy must provide either:
that the policy may not be canceled during the duration of the operations to be performed, or
that the Building Official will be notified in writing, at least 15 days before the policy is canceled.

para.heading: Demolition permits.
para.text: Each application for a demolition permit must:
comply with § 105 {"Permits"} of this Code,
except as provided in § 3303.13.1, be accompanied by a certificate of insurance that evidences compliance with § 3303.10, and
be accompanied by an affidavit to the Building Official that all contracts and other arrangements complying with this Code have been made.

para.heading: Alternative certificate of continuing insurance.
para.text: Instead of providing a separate certificate for each permit, a contractor may provide one general certificate of continuing insurance, as long as the certificate evidences:
the required coverage for all work to be performed by the contractor, and
the insurer's obligation to notify the Building Official, in writing, at least 15 days before the policy is canceled.

para.heading: Methods of demolition.
para.text: The following methods must be used for the demolition of a structure:
The demolition must be performed in approximately the reverse order in which the structure was erected. Where unusual conditions exist, the Building Official may authorize a different method.
Structural elements must be carefully dissembled to avoid collapse.
Heavy pieces of stone or other heavy and bulky materials or equipment must be carefully handled in accordance with this Code.
Demotion must be halted when winds exceed 20 mph.
Wetting is prohibited during periods of prolonged freezing temperatures.

para.heading: Use of explosives.
para.text: The use of explosives is generally prohibited. Explosives for demolition by implosion may be used by special permit from the Building Official.

para.heading: Partial Demolition.
para.text: Building elements that become exposed as result of a partial demolition must be properly finished, braced, or otherwise made safe.

para.heading: Removal of debris.
para.text: The requirements of this section are in addition to those of § 3302.2 {"Waste and debris"}.

para.heading: General requirements.
para.text: Debris on upper floors must be lowered to ground level:
in receptacles, by elevators or hoists, or
in tight and completely enclosed chutes.

para.heading: Chute requirements.
para.text: No chute used for this purpose may extend in an unbroken line that is more than 25 feet (7.62 m) without suitable barriers to prevent debris from falling too fast. Each chute must be equipped with a proper gate or stop at the bottom to control the flow of materials from the chute.

para.heading: Disposition of recyclable debris.
para.text: Whenever recyclable debris to be cleared from a site exceeds 5 tons, at least 30% of that recyclable debris must be immediately transported to a licensed recycling facility.

para.heading: "Recyclable debris" defined.
para.text: In this section, "recyclable debris" means materials that:
if not recycled, would become solid waste for disposal in a solid waste acceptance facility, and
may be collected, separated, or processed and returned to the marketplace in the form of raw materials or products.

para.heading: Correction of injurious conditions.
para.text: This section applies to any demolition contractor who:
performs any demolition work that creates a condition that violates this Code or a condition that might be injurious to the general public or adjourning to adjoining properties, and
refuses or fails to correct the condition in the manner and time required by this Code.

para.heading: Correction by Building Official.
para.text: If the contractor refuses or fails to correct the condition or if an emergency occurs as a result of the condition, the Building Official may correct the condition or perform any other operations necessary to bring the demolition operations into compliance with this Code. All work the Building Official performs under this section is at the expense of the contractor.

para.heading: Contractor not relieved of responsibility.
para.text: The Building Official's performance of any work under this section does not relieve the contractor from responsibility for all work performed by the contractor. Any remedies or penalties provided in this section are in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by law.

para.heading: Limits of liability.
para.text: The liability of any contractor for materials furnished or work done under this Code and the liability of the contractor's surety does not extend to defects in materials or workmanship discovered more than 12 months after the completion of the work. The contractor and surety are responsible to the City to correct all defects discovered during this 12-month period and about which they were notified in writing.

para.heading: Owner's responsibility.
para.text: Notwithstanding the limited liabilities of the contractor and the surety, the owner of the property is responsible at all times to the City to correct any defects in the operations performed on his or her property.

para.heading: Penalty for violation.
para.text: On a contractor's refusal or failure to correct any violation, the contractor's license and all outstanding work permits are automatically suspended. The suspension continues until the violation is corrected.

para.heading: Shared elements – General.
para.text: Repairs to elements shared by a demolished or moved structure and an adjoining structure must comply with all applicable provisions of this Code.

para.heading: Shared elements – Walls.
para.text: Party walls must be repaired and finished by the owner of the demolished or moved structure. The repairs must include:
restoration or replacement of any flashing on adjoining property that has been broken or damaged during the operations,
removal of all plaster from the exposed side of the wall, and
cleaning and finishing the wall with approved waterproof material.

para.heading: Certification required.
para.text: Before any structure may be demolished, moved to another site, or substantially rehabilitated, the applicant for a permit must provide certification from a pesticide applicator licensed by the State of Maryland that all areas of the structure and its lot are free from rodent infestation. A certification of treatment and abatement of all infestation must accompany the permit application.

para.heading: Treatment required.
para.text: Structures or lots found to be infested must be treated by a licensed pesticide applicator before demolition, moving, or rehabilitation

para.heading: Presumption.
para.text: For purposes of this § 3319, any load-bearing wall that is cracked or bowed and any 4-inch load-bearing wall is considered a structurally unsafe wall unless certified to be safe by a professional structural engineer licensed in Maryland.

para.heading: Removal or correction required.
para.text: Any structurally unsafe wall that remains after the demolition or moving of a structure must be:
removed and replaced as required by all applicable sections of this Code, or
in the case of a party wall, corrected as provided in § 3319.3.

para.heading: Party walls.
para.text: If the structurally unsafe wall that remains is a party wall, the owner of the structure being demolished or removed must:
remove all or any part of the wall that the Building Official considers dangerous, and
reconstruct and do all other necessary work to properly enclose the adjoining structure.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This section applies to all operations that involve:
moving or demolishing any structure, or
removing any machinery or equipment from any structure to be moved or demolished.

para.heading: Work to avoid nuisance.
para.text: All operations of the sort described in § 3320.1 must be conducted so that:
no material, object, or thing is allowed to fall in or on any structure or premises or any alley or other public way,
all materials, objects, and things are well wetted down or otherwise treated as needed to prevent dust or other airborne debris, and
no nuisance is otherwise created in the vicinity of the operations.

para.heading: Stop-work order.
para.text: If any operation violates these requirements, the Building Official must issue a stop-work order. Work may resume only after the violation has been corrected and measures taken to prevent a recurrence.

container.heading: Existing Structures
container.text: {MBPS Modification: Rehabilitation work in an existing building must comply with the applicable requirements of the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code, COMAR 05.16.}

para.heading: General.
para.text: This Chapter applies to every single-family dwelling, whether detached, semi-detached, or attached, and to all ground-floor dwelling units of any 2-family dwelling or of any multiple-family dwelling that contains 4 or fewer dwelling units, that:
is newly constructed on a vacant lot, and
receives funding or other assistance from the City or any City agency (including the Housing Authority of Baltimore City) by any one of the following methods:
a building contract or similar agreement that involves any Federal, State, or City funds,
acquisition, by gift, purchase, lease, or otherwise, of any real property for less than its appraised value, as determined by a certified appraiser,
preferential tax treatment, such as payments in lieu of taxes, tax increment financing, or similar benefit,
bond proceeds or issuance assistance, a loan, or similar financial benefit,
receipt under City authority of Federal or State construction funds, including Community Development Block Grant funds, and
except as otherwise specified in this section, receipt of any other form of funding or financial benefit from the City or a City agency.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: This Chapter does not apply to:
additions to or remodelings of existing buildings, or
new construction for which City funding or assistance is limited to either or both:
a property tax credit under City Code Article 28, § 10-5 {"Newly constructed dwellings"}, and
waiver of a City lien on property where the lien exceeds the value of the property.

para.heading: Requirements.
para.text: Every dwelling that is subject to this Chapter must provide at least 1 entrance that:
is accessible to, and usable by, a person with a mobility disability,
does not include steps,
has a level change (including any level change at threshold) that does not exceed ½ inch and, if the level change exceeds ¼ inch, is beveled, and
is located on a continuous unobstructed path that, through the use as necessary or appropriate of curb ramps, parking access aisles, walks, ramps, elevators, lifts, and the like:
connects the lot entrance to the dwelling entrance, and
can be negotiated by a person with a disability who uses a wheelchair, by a person with a disability who does not require use of a wheelchair, and by a person without a disability.

para.heading: "Entry level" defined.
para.text: In this § 3603, "entry level" means the level at which an accessible entrance is provided under § 3602.1 {"Requirements"}.

para.heading: Interior doors.
para.text: On the entry level of the dwelling, each door designed to allow passage must have an unobstructed opening of at least 32 inches when the door is open at a 90-degree angle.

para.heading: "Environmental control" defined.
para.text: In this § 3603.3, "environmental control" means any switch or device that controls or regulates lights, temperature, fuses, fans, doors, security systems, or similar features included in the construction of the dwelling unit.

para.heading: Requirements.
para.text: On the entry level of the dwelling, each environmental control must be located:
no higher than 48 inches above the floor and no lower than 15 inches above the floor, and
if an environmental control is located directly above a counter, sink, or appliance, no higher than 3 inches above the counter, sink, or appliance.

para.heading: Habitable space.
para.text: The entry level of the dwelling must contain at least 1 interior room that:
has an area of not less that 108 sq. ft., and
contains no side or dimension narrower than 9 feet.

para.heading: Bathroom.
para.text: The entry level of the dwelling must contain at least 1 bathroom that contains:
a toilet,
a sink,
reinforced walls at the toilet, to allow for future installation of grab bars, and
the following minimum dimensions:
30"-by-48" of clear floor space outside of the door swing,
30"-by-48" of clear floor space parallel to and centered on the sink, and
48"-by-56" of clear floor space at the toilet for a side approach.

para.heading: General.
para.text: The Building Official may grant a waiver from one or more of the requirements of this Chapter if:
the cost of grading the terrain to meet the requirement is disproportionately expensive in relation to the value of the dwelling,
the width of the lot is less than 16 feet, or
compliance with the requirement is precluded or limited because of the lot's location in a Federal, State, or City historic district.

para.heading: "Disproportionately expensive" defined.
para.text: For purposes of this section, "disproportionately expensive" means that the cost of grading the terrain to meet the requirement exceeds 5% of the fair market value of the unimproved property.

para.heading: Federal and state laws.
para.text: Federal and state laws also govern multiple-family dwellings and public accommodations. Newly constructed multiple-family dwellings may also be subject to the federal Americans with Disabilities Act and the federal Fair Housing Act and their respective guidelines.

para.heading: City law.
para.text: This Chapter applies to some dwellings that are not covered by federal or state law, such as newly-constructed single-family dwellings.

para.heading: More restrictive law controls.
para.text: To the extent that the provisions of this Chapter are not identical to federal or state laws, the more restrictive law controls.

para.heading: General.
para.text: In this Chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of the Department of Transportation or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Gross floor area.
para.text: "Gross floor area" means the area specified in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(j) {"Floor area: Gross (GFA)"}.

para.heading: Change in occupancy.
para.text: "Change in occupancy" has the meaning stated in Baltimore City Building Code § 202.2.12.

para.heading: Traffic-Mitigation Zone.
para.text: "Traffic-Mitigation Zone" or "Zone" means a geographic area designated by this Chapter for heightened review of the potential impact of development on the area's transportation network.

para.heading: Outside a Traffic-Mitigation Zone.
para.text: A traffic-impact study is required for any proposed work outside of a Traffic-Mitigation Zone if the proposed work involves any 1 of the following:
an impact area that includes an intersection performing at Level of Service D or worse,
50 or more dwelling units, or
a gross floor area that equals or exceeds:
for a warehouse use, 100,000 sq. ft., or
for any other use or combination of uses, 50,000 sq. ft.

para.heading: Determination of impact area.
para.text: For purposes of this § 3802.2, an impact area must include the entire area located ½ mile or less from any point on the development's property line, unless the Director, in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under {§ 3803.1 of} this Chapter, determines that extraordinary circumstances exist that require that a larger impact area of up to 1 mile from the development's property line be considered.

para.heading: Within a Traffic-Mitigation Zone.
para.text: A Traffic-Mitigation Fee is required for any proposed new construction or change in occupancy within a Traffic-Mitigation Zone if the proposed work involves any 1 of the following:
10 or more dwelling units, or
a gross floor area that equals or exceeds:
for a warehouse use, 100,000 sq. ft., or
for any other use or combination of uses, 50,000 sq. ft.

para.heading: DoT initial determination.
para.text: Within 20 business days after an application has been referred to the Director of Transportation under § 105.3.1.2 {"Referral to assess need for traffic-mitigation"} of this Code, the Director must review the application and notify the referring official and the applicant:
whether and, if so, what additional information is needed to evaluate the application, or
if no additional information is needed:
whether the proposed project is in a Traffic-Mitigation Zone, and if so,whether the developer of a project must pay a Traffic-Mitigation Fee under § 3806 {"Traffic-Mitigation Fee"} of this Chapter,
whether, under the criteria set forth in this § 3802, a traffic-impact study will be required, and
if a traffic-impact study will be required, the estimated expenses for undertaking or contracting for the study.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Department of Transportation must adopt rules and regulations to carry out this Chapter.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: These rules and regulations:
must include:
procedures for determining the number of trips to be attributable to projects in a particular Traffic-Mitigation Zone or Subzone,

procedures for determining what constitute extraordinary circumstances requiring that an impact area of up to a 1 mile radius be considered for purposes of § 3802.2 {"Outside Traffic-Mitigation Zone"},
a schedule of the fees that an applicant may be charged under § 3804.3 {"Expenses"}, and,
an accounting method, adopted in accordance with § 3807.5.3 {"Accounting
method to be published"}, to identify what specific projects individual fees are obligated to for purposes of a review under § 3807.5.1 {"Review of fee use"},
may establish:
usage categories for determining the number of trips generated by differing uses within Traffic-Mitigation Zones, and
procedures for designating, within Traffic-Mitigation Zones, Subzones with differing trip-generation formulas, and
may include any other procedures, standards, or requirements consistent with this Chapter.

para.heading: Public review.
para.text: In accordance with § 4-301 of the City General Provisions Article, all proposed rules and regulations under this Chapter must be published for public comment for at least 45 days. During the public comment period the Director must hold 3 or more public hearings on the proposed rules and regulations, at least 1 of which must begin between 6 pm and 8 pm.

para.heading: Filing.
para.text: A copy of all rules and regulations adopted under this Chapter must be filed with:
the Building Official,
the Zoning Administrator,
the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals,
the Director of Legislative Reference, and
the Director of Planning.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed §§ 3803.1 and 3803.3 of this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations. (Text Conformed 03/13/21.)

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This § 3804 is applicable to all proposed projects located outside of a Traffic-Mitigation Zone.

para.heading: By DoT or consultant.
para.text: The Department of Transportation may itself undertake the study or contract with independent consultants for the study, as the Director considers necessary or appropriate.

para.heading: Consultant conflicts.
para.text: For a consultant to be eligible to undertake a Traffic-Impact Study, the consultant must certify to the Director, in the manner prescribed by the Director, that the consultant is free of any conflicts of interest.

para.heading: Conflict defined.
para.text: For purposes of this § 3804.2, a "conflict of interest" is defined as any consultant having materially participated in the development of the
application or having worked for the applicant on any application within the prior 24 months.

para.heading: Scope of study.
para.text: The area and scope of each study is to be determined by the Department of Transportation, in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under § 3803 {"DoT rules and regulations"}.

para.heading: Minimum area of study.
para.text: The area of a study required under this § 3804 must not be smaller than the impact area of the project, as determined using the method described in § 3802.2.1 {"Determination of impact area"}.

para.heading: Expenses.
para.text: All reasonable expenses incurred in undertaking or contracting for the study must be paid by the applicant, and will be imposed and collected as provided in § 118 {"Liability for Expenses..."} of this Code for fees and service charges.

para.heading: Initial payment.
para.text: Before the study begins, the applicant must pay the expenses estimated under § 3802.4 {"DoT initial determination"}.

para.heading: Balance.
para.text: After the study is completed, but before any permit may be issued, the applicant must pay any difference between the initial amount paid under § 3804.3.1 and the actual expenses incurred for the study.

para.heading: Refund.
para.text: After the study is completed, subject to appropriation by the Board of Estimates, the applicant is entitled to a refund of any payments made under § 3804.3.1 that exceed the actual expenses incurred for the study plus a reasonable service charge.

para.heading: Applicant's option on delay.
para.text: If the Traffic-Impact Study is not completed within 60 business days after the initial payment is made under § 3804.3.1:

the applicant may proceed to contract for the Traffic-Impact Study with a consultant selected from a list of consultants prequalified by the Department of Public Works' Office of Boards and Commissions; and
subject to appropriation by the Board of Estimates, the applicant is entitled to a full refund of all fees paid to the City for the uncompleted Traffic-Impact Study.

para.heading: Mitigation.
para.text: The applicant and the Department of Transportation must negotiate in good faith to determine who must pay for and undertake the actions necessary or appropriate to mitigate the adverse traffic impacts identified in the Traffic-Impact Study. If no agreement is reached, the application is not approved.

para.heading: Purpose of Zones.
para.text: Areas designated as Traffic-Mitigation Zones are areas that have overburdened and interrelated transportation networks and that are anticipated to experience significant development. Heightened review of development that might impact the transportation networks in these areas is therefore necessary.

para.heading: Traffic-Management Plans for Zones.
para.text: The Planning Commission may adopt a 10-year traffic-management plan for each Traffic-Mitigation Zone and review and update each plan every 5 years.

para.heading: Required plan inclusions.
para.text: Each plan must, among other things:
project the number of trips that reasonably might be expected to be generated in the Zone, based on new development (including redevelopment of vacant and underutilized parcels),
identify multimodal transportation solutions to mitigate the likely growth in traffic congestion, and
based on the Director's recommendations, indicate what projects may be funded, in whole or in part, by Traffic-Mitigation Fees from the Zone.

para.heading: Plan exclusions.
para.text: The plan may not include Traffic-Mitigation Fee funding for system preservation projects such as street resurfacing, reconstruction, or other projects not required to mitigate the growth in traffic congestion unless the system preservation projects are reasonably necessary to improve safety or capacity.

para.heading: Designated Zones.
para.text: There are 5 Traffic-Mitigation Zones in the City of Baltimore.
